p13l15.text: Mobility is a basic need in our everyday lives. We need it for work,

p13l16.text: shopping and in our leisure time. At the same time, it is clear that

p13l17.text: mobility needs to become cleaner. Ethanol made by CropEnergies

p13l18.text: helps you stay mobile – with a clear conscience. Because no other

p13l19.text: renewable energy can improve urban air quality as quickly and easily.

p14l4.text: The 2018/19 reporting year brought progress for renewable energies in the transport sector, after years of, in part, contro­

p14l5.text: versial discussions. The adoption of the European “Renewable Energy Directive” in December 2018 makes a path to less ­

p14l6.text: fossil energy and more greenhouse gas reductions up to 2030 visible. How concrete implementation is to be carried out in

p14l7.text: the member states and who is to make the huge investment in production capacity, infrastructure and vehicles remains to

p14l8.text: be   seen   over   the   next   few   years,   though   this   will   depend,   to   a   significant   extent,   on   the   price   signals   that   the   individual   EU

p14l9.text: member states are prepared to send for fewer greenhouse gas emissions and on the investment strength that the established

p14l11.text: The   supervisory   board   concerned   itself   in   depth   with   the   business   development,   the   financial   position   and   the   business   pros-

p14l12.text: pects of the CropEnergies Group in the reporting year, consulting closely with the executive board. In doing so, the supervisory

p14l13.text: board performed the duties incumbent upon it according to the law, the articles of association and the rules of procedure in

p14l14.text: supervising and advising the executive board in the management of the company’s affairs.

p14l15.text: Cooperation between the supervisory board and the executive board I The supervisory board was directly involved in

p14l16.text: all decisions of fundamental importance relating to the CropEnergies Group and was kept continuously informed in a timely

p14l17.text: and comprehensive manner about the corporate planning, the course of business, the position and the development of the

p14l18.text: CropEnergies Group, including the risk situation, risk management and compliance. The executive board determined the ­strategic

p14l19.text: orientation of CropEnergies in consultation with the supervisory board. The business transactions that are important for the

p14l20.text: company were discussed in detail on the basis of the reports of the executive board.

p14l21.text: The supervisory board chairman had regular contact with the executive board beyond the supervisory board meetings and kept

p14l22.text: himself informed about all events of major importance and the current development of the company’s position. The execu-

p14l23.text: tive   board   also   reported   on   corporate   policy,   profitability,   risk   management   and   the   corporate,   financial,   investment,   research

p14l24.text: and personnel planning related to CropEnergies AG and the CropEnergies Group. The supervisory board chairman delved into

p14l25.text: these topics in numerous working meetings with the executive board.

p14l26.text: Supervisory board meetings and resolutions I Four ordinary meetings of the supervisory board, each of which was attended

p14l27.text: by   the   executive   board,   took   place   in   the   2018/19   financial   year.   Following   thorough   review   and   discussion,   the   supervisory

p14l28.text: board agreed to all the resolution proposals of the executive board.

p14l29.text: No   resolutions   were   passed   by   way   of   written   procedure   in   the   2018/19   financial   year.

p14l30.text: The focal points of the reporting were the developments on the raw materials and sales markets, the hedging of market price

p14l31.text: risks, the political framework conditions for renewable energies, production and the progress of investments, and the cur-

p14l33.text: At its annual account meeting on 14 May 2018,   the   supervisory   board   examined   and   approved   the   annual   financial   state-

p14l34.text: ments   and   management   reports   of   CropEnergies   AG   and   the   consolidated   group   for   2017/18,   issued   with   an   unqualified   audit

p14l35.text: opinion   by   the   independent   auditor,   PricewaterhouseCoopers   GmbH   Wirtschaftsprüfungsgesellschaft   (PwC).   The   independ-

p14l36.text: ent auditor, PwC, reported on the focus and results of the audit, which also included the accounting-related internal control

p14l37.text: system.   After   detailed   discussion,   the   supervisory   board   adopted   the   annual   financial   statements   and   approved   the   consol-

p14l38.text: idated   financial   statements.   The   supervisory   board   prepared   the   2018   annual   general   meeting,   decided   on   the   agenda   and

p15l2.text: addressed the proposal for the election of the independent auditor. It also approved the short- and medium-term investment

p15l3.text: planning and carried out the regular adjustment of the executive board’s compensation structure.

p15l4.text: At the meeting on 17 July 2018 (prior to the annual general meeting), the medium-term planning was presented.

p15l5.text: At the meeting on 12 November 2018,   the   supervisory   board   addressed   the   earnings   projection   for   the   2018/19   financial

p15l6.text: year and approved a supplement to the investment plan. As is always the case at the November meeting, the supervisory

p15l7.text: board   mainly   focused   on   the   issue   of   corporate   governance.   It   conducted   the   annual   review   of   the   efficiency   of   its   activities

p15l8.text: and approved the declaration of conformity for 2018. The supervisory board also addressed the issue of compliance and dis-

p15l10.text: At the meeting on 14 January 2019,   the   updated   earnings   projection   for   the   2018/19   financial   year   was   presented.

p15l19.text: Governance Code, the chairman of the audit committee is not at the same time chairman of the supervisory board.

p16l5.text: Review of the supervisory board’s efficiency I The   supervisory   board   reviewed   the   efficiency   of   its   activities   in   accordance

p16l6.text: with the recommendation pursuant to paragraph 5.6 of the German Corporate Governance Code. This is performed every

p16l7.text: year on the basis of a questionnaire without external support. The questionnaire is adapted in each case to the changes in the

p16l8.text: Code. The evaluation of the questionnaires, the discussion of the results and the deliberations on proposed improvements

p16l9.text: took place at the meeting on 12 November 2018. The objective is the continuous improvement of the activities of the super-

p16l11.text: Compliance I On 8 January 2019, the regular discussion about fraud and corruption risks took place between the independent

p16l12.text: auditor and the chairman of the supervisory board and the audit committee, with information being provided, and subsequent

p16l13.text: discussions held, with regard to the assessment of business risks and measures for limiting the fraud and corruption risks.

p16l14.text: Corporate Governance I Comprehensive information on corporate governance at CropEnergies, including the wording of

p16l15.text: the supervisory board’s diversity objectives for its future composition and the declaration of conformity for 2018 issued jointly

p16l16.text: by the executive board and supervisory board, can be found in the declaration on corporate management on pages 70 – 72

p16l17.text: of the corporate governance report. Additionally, all the relevant information is available on the CropEnergies website

p16l18.text: www.cropenergies.com on the investor relations pages.

p16l19.text: The   executive   board   fulfilled   its   duties,   assigned   to   it   by   law   and   the   rules   of   procedure,   to   inform   the   supervisory   board   in

p16l20.text: an exhaustive and timely manner. The supervisory board also assured itself of the due and proper conduct of the company’s

p16l21.text: affairs and the effectiveness of the company’s organisation and discussed these matters at length in talks with the independ-

p16l22.text: ent auditor. The same applies with regard to the effectiveness of the CropEnergies Group’s risk management system.

p16l23.text: In   the   reporting   period,   the   supervisory   board   was   not   notified   by   any   of   its   members   of   a   conflict   of   interest   –   especially

p16l24.text: no   conflict   of   interest   that   could   arise   as   a   result   of   an   advisory   function   or   position   on   a   board   or   committee   at   customers,

p16l25.text: s­ uppliers, creditors or other business partners.

p16l26.text: Annual financial statements I The independent auditor, PwC, elected by the annual general meeting at the proposal of the

p16l27.text: supervisory   board,   has   audited   the   annual   financial   statements   and   management   report   of   CropEnergies   AG   for   the   2018/19

p16l28.text: financial   year,   and   the   consolidated   financial   statements   and   the   group   management   report   for   2018/19,   and   has   issued   an

p16l29.text: unqualified   audit   opinion   in   each   case.   Furthermore,   the   independent   auditor   has   confirmed   that   the   executive   board   has

p16l30.text: suitably complied with the measures that were incumbent upon it pursuant to § 91 (2) AktG. In particular, it has created an

p16l31.text: appropriate information and monitoring system in line with company requirements that appears suited to its purpose of iden-

p16l32.text: tifying, in good time, developments that could be a threat to the company’s existence. PwC has been auditing the consoli-

p16l33.text: dated   financial   statements   and   the   separate   financial   statements   since   the   2006/07   financial   year.   Since   the   beginning   of   the

p16l34.text: 2016/17   financial   year,   Michael   Conrad   has   been   the   responsible   independent   auditor   at   PwC.

p16l35.text: In   light   of   the   fact   that,   as   of   28   February   2019,   Süddeutsche   Zuckerrüben-Verwertungs-Genossenschaft   eG   (SZVG),   including

p16l36.text: the   69.2%   of   voting   rights   held   by   Südzucker   AG,   directly   and   indirectly   holds   74.4%   of   voting   rights,   the   executive   board   has

p16l37.text: drawn up a report pursuant to § 312 AktG. The independent auditor has reviewed this report, has provided a written report

p16l38.text: on   the   results   of   its   review   and   confirmed   that   the   actual   facts   set   out   in   the   report   are   correct;   payments   by   the   company   in

p17l2.text: connection with legal transactions referred to in the report were not unreasonably high, and no circumstances indicate any

p17l3.text: materially different assessment than that given by the executive board.

p17l4.text: The documents to be examined and the independent auditor’s reports were distributed in good time to each supervisory board

p17l5.text: member. Representatives of the independent auditor, PwC, were present at the audit committee’s meeting on 7 May 2019

p17l6.text: and   at   the   supervisory   board’s   annual   account   meeting   on   13   May   2019,   and   reported   in   detail   on   the   procedures   and   find-

p17l7.text: ings of the audit. After detailed discussions, the supervisory board noted and agreed with the independent auditor’s reports.

p17l8.text: The   findings   of   the   audit   committee’s   prior   review   and   the   findings   of   the   supervisory   board’s   own   review   are   fully   consistent

p17l9.text: with   the   findings   of   the   independent   audit.   The   supervisory   board   raised   no   objections   to   the   financial   statements   presented.

p17l10.text: It   approved   the   annual   financial   statements   of   CropEnergies   AG   prepared   by   the   executive   board   as   well   as   the   consolidated

p17l11.text: financial   statements   of   the   CropEnergies   Group   at   its   meeting   on   13   May   2019;   the   annual   financial   statements   of   CropEnergies

p17l12.text: AG are thereby adopted. The supervisory board has agreed with the executive board’s proposal on the use of the unappropri-

p17l13.text: ated   profit,   with   the   distribution   of   a   dividend   of   €   0.15   per   share.

p17l14.text: Personnel matters I There   were   no   changes   to   the   executive   board   or   the   supervisory   board   in   the   2018/19   financial   year.

p22l71.text: The executive board of CropEnergies AG is solely responsi-

p22l72.text: ble for managing the affairs of the company and is moni-

p22l73.text: tored and advised by the supervisory board in this function.

p22l74.text: The executive board is required to act in the company’s

p23l2.text: interest and obliged to increase sustainable enterprise value.

p23l3.text: The members of the executive board share joint responsi-

p23l4.text: bility for overall management. Notwithstanding this overall

p23l5.text: responsibility, the members of the executive board manage the

p23l6.text: departments assigned to them under their own responsibility

p23l7.text: within the scope of executive board resolutions. The articles of

p23l8.text: association of CropEnergies AG stipulate that important business

p23l9.text: transactions are subject to approval by the supervisory board.

p23l10.text: The executive board is responsible for ensuring that adequate

p23l11.text: risk management and risk controlling procedures are in place

p23l12.text: in the company and works to ensure compliance with legal

p23l13.text: requirements,   official   regulations   and   company-internal   guide-

p23l14.text: lines (compliance). It also ensures that management functions

p23l15.text: within   the   company   are   appropriately   filled.

p23l18.text: CropEnergies deploys a reporting and planning system that

p23l19.text: is uniform across the group and, based on this, applies

p23l20.text: centrally   defined   indicators.   Significant   financial   indica-

p23l21.text: tors are the revenues reported in the income statement,

p23l22.text: oper ating   profit   and   EBITDA.   Operating   profit   is   the   financial

p23l23.text: indicator relevant to management. In the case of the oper-

p23l24.text: ating   profit,   income   from   operations   as   shown   in   the   income

p23l25.text: statement is adjusted for net restructuring costs and special

p23l26.text: items as well as for earnings from entities consolidated at equity.

p23l27.text: Apart   from   operating   profit,   no   further   financial   or   non-financial

p23l28.text: p­ erformance indicators are currently relevant to management.

p23l30.text: Capital management within the CropEnergies Group comprises

p23l31.text: control of cash, equity and debt positions. CropEnergies’ aim

p23l32.text: is a balance sheet structure with a high level of equity, which

p23l33.text: secures the company’s growth strategy, taking standard

p23l34.text: business risks at reasonable capital costs into account with

p23l36.text: The   CropEnergies   Group’s   financing   is   based   on   the   ability

p23l37.text: to   generate   consistently   positive   cash   flows,   stable   relations

p23l38.text: with the shareholder groups backing the company, access to

p23l39.text: the capital markets and reliable banking relationships. The

p23l40.text: communication with capital market participants pursues a

p23l41.text: policy   of   financial   transparency   based   on   a   reporting   system

p23l42.text: which   defines   both   the   corporate   planning   and   the   reporting

p23l43.text: processes, using the same valuation and disclosure principles.

p23l45.text: The CropEnergies Group’s mission is to work in concert with

p23l46.text: its partners to shape the future responsibly and to develop

p23l47.text: solutions today for the social and corporate challenges of

p23l48.text: tomorrow,   focusing   on   a   responsible,   efficient   and   beneficial

p23l49.text: use of all raw materials used and their components. The prod-

p23l50.text: ucts produced aim to improve the quality of life for the pres-

p23l51.text: ent generation while safeguarding that of future generations.

p23l52.text: As one of the leading European producer of sustainably gen-

p23l53.text: erated ethanol, CropEnergies combines business success with

p23l54.text: social responsibility and environmental protection. The com-

p23l55.text: pany’s   aim   is   to   grow   profitably,   to   increase   enterprise   value

p23l56.text: in the long term and to take the interests of shareholders,

p23l57.text: customers, suppliers and employees into account, through

p23l59.text: CropEnergies’ broad product portfolio includes ethanol, the

p23l60.text: world’s No. 1 biofuel, which is produced from the starch or

p23l61.text: sugar content of renewable raw materials. Sustainably produced

p23l62.text: ethanol is proven to reduce greenhouse gases, conserves the

p23l63.text: world’s   finite   fossil   resources   and,   as   a   climate-friendly   substi-

p23l64.text: tute for petrol, ensures, among other things, clean mobility in

p23l65.text: the future. CropEnergies produces, in particular, protein-rich

p23l66.text: food and animal feed products, which also contain valuable

p23l67.text: dietary   fibres,   fats,   minerals   and   vitamins,   from   the   remain-

p23l68.text: ing components of the raw materials used. These products

p23l69.text: have a high nutritional value and make an important contri-

p23l70.text: bution to reducing European import requirements for vegeta-

p23l71.text: ble proteins, particularly soy from North and South America.

p24l2.text: The CropEnergies Group achieves its objectives through operat-

p24l3.text: ing excellence and innovations, relying on its own core compe-

p24l4.text: tences – the large-scale processing of raw materials into high-

p24l5.text: grade   products   in   biorefineries   and   their   marketing.   What   is

p24l6.text: crucial here is the extensive know-how across the entire value

p24l7.text: chain – from crop growing to production through to trans-

p24l8.text: port   and   marketing.   With   its   innovative   production   facilities,

p24l9.text: CropEnergies   sets   standards   in   terms   of   technology,   efficiency

p24l10.text: and   flexibility.   This   is   complemented   by   an   efficient   sourcing

p24l11.text: management and an optimised logistics network. The com-

p24l12.text: pany’s extensive experience at all value creation and process

p24l13.text: stages makes it a reliable partner, too. CropEnergies intends

p24l14.text: to use innovations to secure a competitive edge in the exist-

p24l15.text: ing activities, tap new markets and develop solutions for the

p24l16.text: challenges of the future. Key to the company’s success are

p24l17.text: the knowledge, experience, social skills, satisfaction and

p24l18.text: dedication of its employees. The company also aims to con-

p24l19.text: tinue to develop these strengths by training and advancing

p24l28.text: CropEnergies operates sustainably in the interest of the com-

p24l29.text: pany’s successful development and a future worth living.

p25l5.text: The main prerequisite for CropEnergies’ success is sustainable

p25l6.text: business activity, i.e., reconciling ecology, economics and social

p25l7.text: responsibility. An essential component of the business model

p25l8.text: is the simultaneous production of valuable food and animal

p25l9.text: feed products as well as a sustainable alternative to fossil fuel.

p25l10.text: Sustainability   is   also   a   significant   business   factor   for   our   cus-

p25l12.text: low-emission transport sector, oil companies are increas-

p26l3.text: CropEnergies’ sustainability activities begin as early as the

p26l4.text: upstream stages of the value chain, particularly in respect

p26l6.text: procurement of raw materials. CropEnergies uses only raw

p26l7.text: materials of European origin that are mostly procured close

p26l8.text: to the respective site. The transport routes are commensu-

p26l10.text: All   raw   material   suppliers   in   the   EU   fulfil   the   principles   of

p26l11.text: cross-compliance applicable to agricultural production with

p26l12.text: the corresponding requirements for agriculture, which ensure

p26l13.text: that raw materials are grown sustainably. The sustainability

p26l14.text: criteria for raw materials for the production of biofuels even

p26l15.text: go beyond the cross-compliance requirements. They stipu-

p26l16.text: late, for example, that the raw materials must not be grown

p26l17.text: in   sensitive   areas   such   as   first-growth   forests   (e.g.,   rain -

p26l18.text: forest) or in areas of high biological diversity. In order to guar-

p26l19.text: antee this, all interfaces involved in production are regularly

p26l20.text: audited by independent and recognised experts and certi-

p26l21.text: fied   in   accordance   with   certification   systems   recognised   by

p26l22.text: the EU (e.g., REDcert EU, ISCC EU or 2BSvs). Compliance with

p26l23.text: the sustainability criteria is laid down in the contracts with

p26l28.text: It is the aim of CropEnergies, in processing raw materials into

p26l29.text: ethanol, food and animal feed products, to minimise resource

p26l30.text: requirements, energy and water use and possible environ-

p26l31.text: mental impact whilst observing the highest quality standards.

p26l32.text: Thanks to its integrated production concepts, the raw materi-

p26l33.text: als   used   are   refined   into   high-grade   products   in   the   best   pos-

p26l36.text: valuable   dietary   fibres,   fats,   minerals   and   vitamins,   from   the

p26l37.text: non-fermentable contents of the raw materials. These prod-

p26l39.text: contribution to reducing European import requirements for

p26l40.text: vegetable proteins, particularly soy from North and South

p26l41.text: America. Furthermore, the carbon dioxide produced during

p26l43.text: replaces carbon dioxide of fossil origin in the manufacture of

p26l44.text: beverages, for instance. CropEnergies thus fully exploits the

p28l27.text: The   proportion   of   renewable   fuels   used   is   24%.   At   Wanze,   a

p28l28.text: large part of the thermal and electric process energy required

p28l29.text: is produced in a biomass plant directly from the husks of the

p28l30.text: delivered   wheat,   the   bran.   At   Zeitz,   the   biomethane   (sewage

p28l31.text: gas) produced in the sewage treatment plant is being con-

p28l47.text: Water   is   used   and   discharged   in   a   sustainable   manner   at   all

p28l48.text: sites. A hallmark of CropEnergies’ production plants is that

p28l49.text: fresh water needs are considerably reduced by recycling and

p28l50.text: hence multiple use of the water deployed.

p28l65.text: Waste   water   treatment   plants   ensure   that   the   waste   water   is

p28l66.text: treated in an environmentally responsible manner. The water

p28l67.text: that has been cleaned is returned to neighbouring rivers.

p29l3.text: As the components contained in the raw materials are almost

p29l4.text: completely   refined   into   protein-rich   or   carbohydrate-rich   prod-

p29l5.text: ucts, very little waste is generated. Most of the waste materi-

p29l6.text: als (95%) are recycled, composted or used to produce energy.

p29l7.text: Less than 0.1% of the waste materials are hazardous waste.

p29l8.text: These consist primarily of used lubricants from production.

p30l3.text: CropEnergies attaches central importance to the production of

p30l4.text: safe and high-quality products and is conscious of the accom-

p30l5.text: panying responsibility. That is why it has a quality manage-

p30l6.text: ment system that lays down a structured and effective pro-

p30l7.text: cedure for all stages of production.

p30l9.text: The   quality   management   system   defines   measures   that   ensure

p30l10.text: that   all   products   comply   with   the   statutory   specifications   and

p30l11.text: customers’ requirements. The HACCP concept is a central

p30l12.text: element of the CropEnergies quality management system.

p30l13.text: A structured hazard analysis is used to examine each indi-

p30l14.text: vidual step in the production of food in respect of potential

p30l15.text: hazards for the health of consumers and in the production of

p30l16.text: animal feed in respect of animal health, with corresponding

p30l17.text: countermeasures being initiated immediately where necessary.

p30l18.text: Other essential elements of quality management relate to long-

p30l19.text: term   supplier   relationships   and   detailed   raw   material   specifi-

p30l20.text: cations,   qualified   employees,   safe   production   processes   and

p30l40.text: Value-oriented   and   profitable   growth   serves   as   the   basis   for

p30l49.text: development of the regional economy, particularly farms.

p30l56.text: The   location   of   CropEnergies’   biorefineries   is   geared   to   avoid-

p30l57.text: ing emissions. The sites are therefore located in the vicinity

p30l58.text: of large grain-growing areas, water routes or railways. This

p30l59.text: shortens transport routes or enables deliveries to be made in

p30l60.text: an environmentally friendly manner, mostly via sea or rail. In

p30l61.text: Wanze,   for   example,   around   70%   of   the   raw   materials   used

p30l62.text: are   delivered   via   sea.   The   plant   in   Zeitz   is,   in   turn,   part   of   the

p30l63.text: network   for   sugar   and   starch   production   of   Südzucker   AG   and

p30l64.text: is connected to the latter via a pipeline.

p30l65.text: On the sales side, too, the optimisation of the distribution

p30l66.text: logistics to the end customer is playing a more and more

p30l67.text: important role in terms of competitiveness and ecology. End

p30l68.text: customers are therefore likewise mostly supplied via sea or

p31l23.text: The high priority given to health and safety is indispensable

p34l4.text: For CropEnergies AG as the leading European producer of

p34l5.text: ethanol in a technology-oriented environment, research and

p34l6.text: development is an integral part of its strategic orientation.

p34l7.text: Research   and   development   activities   focus   on   refining   specific

p34l8.text: key technologies and tapping new ones so as to boost com-

p34l9.text: petitiveness in the area of climate-friendly fuels and to make

p34l10.text: a contribution to sustainable development through alterna-

p34l11.text: tive concepts for using ethanol and co-products.

p34l46.text: Fermentation is the technologically most demanding process

p34l47.text: step   in   ethanol   production.   In   addition   to   raw   material   influ-

p34l48.text: ences, the continuous analysis of new enzymes and yeasts in

p34l49.text: terms   of   efficiency   and   cost-effectiveness   is   an   important   part

p34l50.text: of research activities. The goal is to optimise the ethanol yields

p34l51.text: and the conversion speed from the raw materials employed.

p34l52.text: New, non-GMO yeasts have been tested on a laboratory scale

p34l53.text: in a research project with an industrial partner. During the

p34l54.text: project, extremely positive effects on ethanol yield emerged.

p34l55.text: Large-scale production of these yeasts has now been tested

p34l56.text: and implemented, resulting in the insights acquired in the lab-

p34l57.text: oratory being able to be further evaluated, in a production

p34l58.text: trial   with   regard   to   raw   material   and   plant-specific   parame-

p34l59.text: ters as well as economic criteria.

p34l60.text: In addition to the biotechnological activities, new technol-

p34l61.text: ogies for optimising starch decomposition have also been

p34l62.text: tested. It was possible to demonstrate the positive effects

p34l63.text: by means of industry-scale factory trials. The cost-effective-

p34l64.text: ness of corresponding investment for integrating these tech-

p34l65.text: nologies into existing plants is currently being investigated.

p34l66.text: Programmes for improving the microbiological quality in fer-

p34l67.text: mentation through adjustment of process parameters have

p34l68.text: been implemented. They resulted in a reduction in the use of

p34l69.text: yeast and in improved ethanol yields.

p34l73.text: the testing of new technologies for de-watering the material

p34l74.text: flows   arising   in   production.   The   aim   is   for   such   de-watering

p35l2.text: to   be   carried   out   more   efficiently   and   more   cost-effectively

p35l3.text: owing to lower primary energy use.

p35l5.text: improved,   which   should   contribute   to   the   energy-efficient

p35l7.text: In   Wilton,   further   potential   improvements   were   analysed   and

p35l8.text: implemented with a view, for example, to increasing process

p35l9.text: stability and ethanol yield. The optimisation of yeast and

p35l16.text: The quality of neutral alcohol depends on the purity of the

p35l17.text: end   product   and   the   sensory   impression,   which   is   also   influ-

p35l18.text: enced by the raw materials used. If the alcohol is to be used

p35l19.text: in food or in pharmaceutical and cosmetic industry products,

p35l20.text: its odour and taste neutrality is the crucial quality parame-

p35l21.text: ter. Sensory studies, in particular, were carried out to evalu-

p35l22.text: ate alternative producers of drying media in accordance with

p35l23.text: these framework conditions. Furthermore, new drying tech-

p35l24.text: nologies were tested and compared with the existing plant

p35l25.text: configurations   in   both   technological   and   economic   terms.

p35l37.text: bustion. At the same time, particulate emissions are lower.

p35l52.text: The processing of protein-containing side-streams for food

p35l54.text: The EU “PROMINENT” project has used innovative processes

p35l55.text: and technologies to investigate the extraction of functional

p35l56.text: proteins from the side-streams of ethanol production. The

p35l57.text: project consortium involving European partners from industry

p35l58.text: and academia succeeded in isolating initial functional proteins.

p35l59.text: Their use in food applications is being tested. The research

p35l60.text: project has shown that additional valuable materials can be

p35l61.text: acquired during ethanol production using special technologies.

p35l67.text: transfer the process parameters obtained to the new technical

p35l68.text: plant   at   the   Wanze   site,   which   started   operating   in   March   2019.

p36l25.text: Quality management for food and animal feed

p36l26.text: The safety concepts (HACCP) and quality levels produced for

p36l27.text: all of CropEnergies’ animal feed and food products are reg-

p36l28.text: ularly reviewed and updated. The relevant monitoring data

p36l29.text: is evaluated to this end and summarised in quality reports.

p36l30.text: Inspection plans for quality control and monitoring are kept

p36l31.text: up   to   date   in   parallel.   In   the   past   financial   year,   the   inspec-

p36l32.text: tion plans, analysis methods and HACCP documentation were

p36l33.text: extended to the production of meat alternatives.

p36l34.text: CropEnergies’ interests in respect of animal feed products,

p36l35.text: chemical contaminants, pesticide residues, mycotoxins and

p36l36.text: enzymes are also represented in associations.

p39l3.text: As a responsible employer, CropEnergies does not tolerate

p39l4.text: discrimination of any kind. Its binding code of conduct, which

p39l5.text: is based on international standards, prohibits discrimination,

p39l6.text: harassment, child labour and forced labour and is committed

p39l7.text: to freedom of association, health, and safety at work. ­Flexible

p39l8.text: working times, the possibility of teleworking and codes of

p39l9.text: conduct regarding, for example, availability are designed to

p39l10.text: contribute to protecting the health of employees and to make

p39l11.text: CropEnergies more attractive as an employer.

p39l13.text: The performance and dedication of its employees are the

p39l14.text: determining factors in the CropEnergies Group’s success.

p39l15.text: Again   in   the   past   financial   year,   they   showed   great   commit-

p39l16.text: ment in working for the corporate success and further devel-

p39l17.text: opment of the CropEnergies Group, resulting in our company

p39l18.text: also being well equipped for the future. The executive board

p39l19.text: wishes to express its sincere thanks to all employees and looks

p42l2.text: Brazil I In Brazil, ethanol production in the 2018/19 sugar year,

p42l3.text: at an expected 32.6 (27.8) million m3, rose to a new record

p42l4.text: level. This was mainly due to vibrant domestic demand of

p42l5.text: 32.1 (28.4) million m3. Owing to a largely balanced supply situ­

p42l6.text: ation, there continued to be no major net exports of ethanol.

p42l7.text: Similar market conditions are expected in the 2019/20 sugar

p42l8.text: year, which means that both production and consumption

p42l9.text: of ethanol are likely to be around 32.5 million m3. The lively

p42l10.text: domestic demand is due, not least, to a temporary fall in eth-

p42l11.text: anol prices. Ethanol in Brazil declined in price from the equiv-

p42l12.text: alent of around € 490/m3 at the beginning of March 2018 to

p42l13.text: around € 335/m3 at the end of August 2018. Prices were able

p42l14.text: to recover again to around € 445/m3 by the end of February

p42l15.text: 2019. This development is consistent with low sugar prices:

p42l16.text: At the end of September 2018, they reached their lowest level

p42l17.text: for 10 years on the New York stock exchange.

p42l19.text: in the EU in 2018, with fuel ethanol accounting for

p42l20.text: 5.4 (5.3) million m3. Domestic ethanol consumption stood

p42l21.text: at 8.0 (7.9) million m3, with fuel ethanol accounting for

p42l22.text: 5.4 (5.3) million m3. Imports are expected to undergo little

p42l25.text: level of 8.0 (8.0) million m3 in the 2019 calendar year, while it

p42l26.text: expects production to be slightly below the previous year’s level.

p42l49.text: European ethanol prices proved to be extremely volatile and

p42l50.text: prone to market speculations in the reporting period. The ini-

p42l51.text: tial focus was on speculations about the impact of the dis-

p42l52.text: continuation of the EU sugar market system in October 2017,

p42l53.text: but these were joined by speculations about rising raw mate-

p42l54.text: rial costs due to drought-related harvest failures in parts of

p42l55.text: Europe, degrees of utilisation of individual European plants

p42l56.text: and the advantageousness of imports as well as low water-

p42l58.text: Short-term forward prices initially followed weak interna-

p42l59.text: tional trends, declining from around € 465/m3 fob Rotter-

p42l60.text: dam at the beginning of March 2018 to around € 440/m3 in

p42l63.text: quarter   of   the   2018/19   financial   year.   In   the   further

p42l64.text: half,   of   the   financial   year,   etha-

p42l65.text: nol prices recovered, standing at around € 560/m3 at the end

p42l66.text: of February 2019. At € 430 to € 620/m3, ethanol prices in the

p42l67.text: EU again ranged widely, but the rapid changes can hardly be

p42l68.text: explained by the real market conditions.

p42l69.text: In Germany, the largest market for ethanol in the EU, fuel etha-

p42l70.text: nol consumption in 2018 remained at the previous year’s level

p42l71.text: of 1.5 (1.5) million m3. There was likewise little or no change to

p42l72.text: sales of E10, at 2.4 (2.4) million tonnes. Fuel ethanol achieved

p42l73.text: a share of 4.2% (4.1%) of the German petrol fuel market.

p43l2.text: Developments on the raw material and protein markets

p43l3.text: Grain markets I According to its forecast for the 2018/19 grain

p43l4.text: year published on 28 March 2019, the International Grains

p43l5.text: Council (IGC) expects world grain production (excluding rice)

p43l6.text: of 2,125 (2,142) million tonnes. Given world grain consumption

p43l7.text: of 2,170 (2,153) million tonnes, it expects stocks to decline to

p43l9.text: The European Commission expects the EU to have a lower

p43l10.text: grain harvest of 291 (305) million tonnes in the 2018/19 grain

p43l11.text: year owing to the severe drought in large parts of Europe.

p43l12.text: Consumption is expected to be largely at the previous year’s

p43l13.text: level,   at   287   (286)   million   tonnes.   Owing   to   the   significant

p43l14.text: harvest failures, the one-month futures contract for milling

p43l15.text: wheat on the Euronext in Paris rose from € 167/tonne at the

p43l16.text: beginning of March 2018 to around € 200/tonne by the end

p43l17.text: of July 2018 and has largely hovered around this mark since.

p43l18.text: The listing closed at € 193/tonne at the end of February 2019.

p43l19.text: The International Grains Council (IGC) forecasts global grain

p43l20.text: production of 2,175 (2,125) million tonnes in the 2019/20

p43l21.text: grain year. Grain consumption is expected to continue to

p43l22.text: rise to 2,204 (2,170) million tonnes. Global grain stocks at

p43l23.text: the end of 2019/20 are accordingly expected to decline to

p43l25.text: For the 2019/20 grain year, the European Commission expects

p43l26.text: 308 million tonnes of grain to be harvested in the EU. Grain

p43l27.text: demand is set to continue to remain stable, at 287 million

p43l28.text: tonnes, with over 60% continuing to be used for animal feed

p43l29.text: products. By contrast, the starch content of only 13 million

p43l30.text: tonnes of grain or around 4% of the EU harvest is expected

p43l31.text: to be used for the production of fuel ethanol. In view of the

p43l34.text: nol production, the ethanol industry will contribute to reduc-

p43l35.text: ing market pressure and securing agricultural incomes in this

p43l72.text: Sugar markets I While   a   significant   production   surplus   had

p43l73.text: been expected in summer 2018 for the current sugar year

p43l74.text: of 2018/19, the most recent estimates show that the mar-

p43l75.text: ket is balanced in the 2018/19 sugar year and that there

p43l76.text: will   be   a   slight   deficit   of   1.5   million   tonnes   in   the   sugar

p43l77.text: year of 2019/20. The white sugar futures contract (next

p43l78.text: expiry date) declined from the equivalent of € 300/tonne

p43l79.text: on the ICE in London and was trading at € 250/tonne in

p43l80.text: April 2018. The last time such a low price level was observable

p43l81.text: was in January 2009. The sugar price was able to stabi-

p43l82.text: lise   somewhat   in   the   course   of   the   financial   year,   closing   at

p43l84.text: The   previous   2017/18   sugar   year   was   the   first   since   the   discon-

p43l85.text: tinuation of sugar quota rules and minimum sugar beet prices

p43l86.text: in the EU. An increase in the growing area and above-aver-

p43l87.text: age yields resulted in EU sugar production (including isoglu-

p43l88.text: cose)   of   22   million   tonnes.   With   declining   imports,   the   EU’s

p43l89.text: exports   rose   to   a   level   of   3.4   million   tonnes,   for   the   first   time

p43l90.text: since 2006. The European Commission expects sugar produc-

p43l91.text: tion   to   decline   significantly   in   the   2018/19   sugar   year   owing   to

p43l92.text: the severe drought in large beet growing areas. Given virtu-

p43l93.text: ally unchanged growing areas and below-average yields, sugar

p43l94.text: production is expected to decline to 18 (22) million tonnes.

p43l95.text: With   largely   stable   imports,   this   will   mainly   be   reflected   in

p44l2.text: Protein markets I During the production of ethanol from

p44l3.text: grain, only the starch contained in the corn is converted into

p44l4.text: alcohol. CropEnergies processes any additionally contained

p44l5.text: components, among other things, into protein-rich food and

p44l6.text: animal feed products, which also contain valuable vitamins,

p44l7.text: minerals   and   dietary   fibres.   The   prices   of   these   products   are

p44l8.text: particularly affected by the price level of soy on the world

p44l9.text: market and rapeseed meal prices in Europe.

p44l10.text: According to the IGC, the global soybean harvest in 2018/19

p44l11.text: will   increase   significantly,   to   359   (341)   million   tonnes,   and   set

p44l12.text: a new record. Soybean demand is also developing vibrantly

p44l13.text: and is expected to reach 352 (345) million tonnes. Accordingly,

p44l14.text: rising stocks of 52 (45) million tonnes are expected. This devel-

p44l15.text: opment resulted in the one-month soybean futures contract

p44l16.text: on CBOT standing at US$ 9/bushel* at the end of February

p44l17.text: 2019,   i.e.,   significantly   below   the   level   of   US$   10.60/bushel

p44l18.text: at the beginning of March 2018. On 13 July 2018, soybeans

p44l19.text: cost as little as US$ 8.14/bushel on the exchange in Chicago,

p44l20.text: which was their lowest level for almost ten years. By con-

p44l21.text: trast, European rapeseed meal prices declined only slightly

p44l22.text: year over year to € 220 (225)/tonne as of the end of February

p44l23.text: 2019. This was due to a mainly drought-related lower rape-

p44l24.text: seed harvest in the EU of 20 (22) million tonnes in 2018/19.

p44l26.text: Current framework in the EU I In the EU, the “Renewable

p44l27.text: Energy Directive” is setting the course for more sustainability

p44l28.text: and climate protection in the transport sector. The proportion

p44l29.text: of renewable energies in this sector is set to increase to 10%

p44l30.text: by 2020, with renewable fuels from arable crops being able

p44l31.text: to account for up to 7%. The remaining gap can be closed by

p44l32.text: fuels from wastes and residues or renewable electricity used

p44l33.text: in   rail   and   road   transport,   which   benefit   additionally   from

p44l34.text: double or multiple counting towards the renewable energies

p44l35.text: target in the transport sector. Renewable fuels must comply

p44l36.text: with strict sustainability criteria. This includes provision of

p44l37.text: proof that they reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least

p44l38.text: 50 wt.-% in comparison with fossil fuels, calculated across

p44l39.text: the entire value chain. Furthermore, complete documentation

p44l40.text: of the origin of the raw materials used for the biofuel produc-

p44l42.text: In addition, the “Fuel Quality Directive” stipulates that green-

p44l43.text: house gas emissions associated with fuel consumption must

p44l44.text: be reduced by 6 wt.-% compared with the base value of

p44l46.text: eq/MJ by the year 2020. In relation to a litre of

p44l47.text: petrol, that is equivalent to greenhouse gas emissions of

p44l50.text: ethanol from European raw materials reduces greenhouse gas

p44l52.text: 2030 climate and energy package I After the European

p44l53.text: Commission, on 30 November 2016, had proposed a new

p44l54.text: version of the “Renewable Energy Directive” for the period

p44l55.text: after   2020,   the   latter   was   published   in   the   Official   Journal   of

p44l56.text: the European Union on 21 December 2018 and entered into

p44l57.text: force on 24 December 2018. This had been preceded by two

p44l58.text: years of discussions and negotiations between the European

p44l59.text: Parliament and the Council, during which key points of the

p44l60.text: original Commission proposal were amended. The proportion

p44l61.text: of renewable energies in the EU is now set to rise to at least

p44l62.text: 32% by 2030. In contrast to the original European Commission

p44l63.text: draft document, Parliament and Council were also in favour

p44l64.text: of   a   specific   target   for   the   transport   sector   of   at   least   14%.

p44l65.text: Renewable fuels from arable crops can continue to provide an

p44l66.text: important   proportion   of   this   figure.   Their   contribution   should

p44l67.text: be able to remain up to one percentage point above the level

p44l68.text: reached in 2020. At the same time, the use of biofuels whose

p44l69.text: raw material extraction has resulted in a loss of high-carbon

p44l70.text: areas (e.g., rain forest) is to be gradually reduced from 2023

p44l71.text: onwards and stopped by 2030. The proportion of fuels from

p44l72.text: wastes and residues is to rise from 0.2% in 2022 to at least

p44l73.text: 3.5% in 2030. In addition, these fuels, as well as renewable

p44l74.text: electricity in road transport, can be counted multiple times

p44l76.text: * A bushel of soybeans is equivalent to 27.216 kg of soybeans.

p45l2.text: The follow-on regulation up to 2030 that has now been put

p45l3.text: in place offers a chance that sustainably produced renewable

p45l4.text: fuels can contribute to climate protection on Europe’s roads

p45l5.text: even after 2020. This also requires E10 to be extensively intro-

p45l6.text: duced into all EU member states. It is therefore gratifying to

p45l7.text: note that both the Parliament and the Council have agreed on

p45l8.text: a minimum proportion of renewable energies in the transport

p45l9.text: sector and its increase by the year 2030. It is likewise construc-

p45l10.text: tive that renewable fuels from domestic arable crops should

p45l11.text: continue to be able to contribute to lowering the consumption

p45l12.text: of fossil fuels and improving the climate footprint of fuels.

p45l13.text: Based on this, other renewable fuels from wastes and resi-

p45l14.text: dues   can   reduce   the   consumption   of   fossil   fuels.   What   must

p45l15.text: be critically evaluated, however, is the multiple counting of

p45l16.text: certain fuels and energy sources, as this virtual increase in

p45l17.text: the renewable energy proportion will lower neither the con-

p45l18.text: sumption of fossil fuels nor their emissions. On the contrary,

p45l19.text: multiple counting will maintain the consumption of fossil

p45l20.text: fuels from imported crude oil. It is now up to the EU member

p45l21.text: states to implement the European targets at national level in

p45l22.text: such a way that the consumption of fossil fuels is actually low-

p45l23.text: ered and the climate footprint of fuels improved. The mem-

p45l24.text: ber states have until 30 June 2021 to do this.

p45l25.text: Germany I In Germany, a greenhouse gas reduction target

p45l26.text: of 4.0 wt.-% for fuels has applied since 1 January 2017. This

p45l27.text: will be raised to 6.0 wt.-% from 2020 onwards. Relative to the

p45l28.text: greenhouse gas base value of 94.1 g CO2eq

p45l29.text: Belgien I In Belgium, the share of sustainable biofuels is to

p45l30.text: increase to 8.5% of fuel consumption from 2020 onwards.

p45l31.text: To achieve the target, the energy content of sustainably pro-

p45l32.text: duced ethanol in petrols is to rise from around 5.6% at present

p45l33.text: (8.5 vol.-%) to 6.5%. Furthermore, biofuels from wastes and

p45l34.text: residues up to a proportion of 0.6% are to be able to be counted

p45l35.text: double towards the overall target. E10, which was introduced

p45l36.text: in 2017, also maintained its market position as the standard

p45l37.text: petrol fuel in 2018, achieving a market share of around 80%.

p45l38.text: United Kingdom I The minimum proportion for renewa-

p45l39.text: ble energies in fuels was raised in the United Kingdom from

p45l40.text: 4.75 vol.-% to 7.25 vol.-% in April 2018. There was a further

p45l41.text: increase to 8.5 vol.-% with effect from 1 January 2019. The

p45l42.text: proportion of renewable fuels is to increase to 9.75 vol.-% in

p45l43.text: 2020 and, in further increments, ultimately to 12.4 vol.-%

p45l44.text: from 2032 onwards. In addition to renewable fuels from arable

p45l45.text: crops, which are initially allowed to contribute up to 4 vol.-%

p45l46.text: towards the achievement of the target up to 2020 before grad-

p45l47.text: ually decreasing this contribution to 2 vol.-% from 2032, the

p45l48.text: use, in particular, of renewable fuels from wastes and resi-

p45l49.text: dues as well as renewable fuels for particular uses (e.g., air

p45l52.text: form across the EU, the fuel ethanol used in Germany in 2017

p45l53.text: showed greenhouse gas emissions of merely 14.6 g CO2eq

p45l55.text: This is equivalent to a reduction of 85% of greenhouse gases,

p45l56.text: across   the   entire   value   chain   from   the   field   right   through   to   use

p45l57.text: in a vehicle. According to German legislation, renewable fuels

p45l58.text: from arable crops can be used up to a 6.5% share of energy.

p45l59.text: The proportion of renewable fuels from wastes and residues

p45l60.text: is to rise from 0.05% in 2020 to 0.5% from 2025 onwards.

p45l61.text: France I In France, the blending obligation for petrol fuels

p45l62.text: was increased from the previous level of 7.5% to 7.9% in

p45l63.text: 2019 and to 8.2% in 2020. In the diesel segment, the mini-

p45l64.text: mum proportions were increased to 7.9% (2019) and 8.0%

p45l65.text: (2020). Renewable fuels from arable crops can contribute up

p45l66.text: to 7% to each of these. The remaining gap is to be covered

p45l67.text: by fuels from sugar- or starch-containing processing residues

p45l68.text: or by biofuels from wastes and residues. The latter can, to a

p45l69.text: limited extent, also be counted double towards the blending

p45l70.text: targets. The proportion of renewable energies in the trans-

p45l71.text: port sector is set to increase to 15% by 2030. E10 was able

p45l72.text: to further strengthen its position as the leading petrol variety

p45l73.text: on the French petrol fuel market, its share standing at 47%

p56l66.text: Apart from developments on the sales and raw materials mar-

p56l67.text: kets, political will and the corresponding framework are also

p56l68.text: crucial to the success of renewable energies in the transport

p56l69.text: sector. The proportion of renewable energies in this sector is

p56l70.text: set to increase to 10% by 2020, with renewable fuels from

p56l71.text: arable   crops   certified   as   sustainable   being   able   to   account   for

p56l72.text: up to 7%. The remaining 3% are to be achieved by means of

p56l73.text: fuels from wastes and residues or renewable electricity used

p56l74.text: in rail and road transport. In view of the short time frame until

p56l75.text: 2020, numerous member states, including France, Finland, the

p56l76.text: Netherlands and Spain, have increased their national targets

p56l77.text: for renewable fuels at the beginning of 2019.

p57l2.text: Furthermore, the proportion of renewable energies in fuels was

p57l3.text: raised in the United Kingdom from 7.25 vol.-% to 8.5 vol.-%

p57l4.text: with effect from 1 January 2019. The proportion of renewa-

p57l5.text: ble fuels is to continue to increase gradually to 9.75 vol.-% in

p57l6.text: 2020. The new regulation should result in an increase in etha-

p57l7.text: nol demand insofar as extensive use is made of E10.

p60l26.text: For CropEnergies, the responsible handling of entrepreneurial

p60l27.text: opportunities and risks is an integral part of sustainable, val-

p60l28.text: ue-oriented   corporate   management.   CropEnergies   defines   risk

p60l29.text: and opportunities as future developments or events that can

p60l30.text: have a negative or positive effect on the achievement of stra-

p60l31.text: tegic goals and operational plans. Assessing risks and utilising

p60l32.text: opportunities serves to safeguard the company and extend

p60l33.text: its competitiveness. To that end, CropEnergies uses an inte-

p60l34.text: grated system for the early detection and monitoring of busi-

p60l35.text: ness-specific   risks.   The   successful   treatment   of   risks   is   based

p60l36.text: on achieving a balanced relationship between return and risks.

p60l37.text: The company’s risk culture is characterised by risk-conscious

p60l38.text: conduct,   clearly   defined   responsibilities,   independence   during

p60l39.text: risk controlling and the implementation of internal controls.

p60l40.text: Where   possible   and   economically   viable,   insurable   risks   are

p60l41.text: covered by a cross-group insurance programme.

p60l43.text: Risk management is an integral part of the overall planning,

p60l44.text: controlling   and   reporting   processes   and   is   defined   by   the   exec-

p60l45.text: utive board. It must ensure that existing risks are detected,

p60l46.text: analysed and assessed early and systematically and that

p60l47.text: risk-related information is properly forwarded to the rele-

p60l48.text: vant decision-makers. All employees are urged to communi-

p60l49.text: cate any impending or existing risks immediately to their line

p60l50.text: managers. This enables CropEnergies to ensure that risks are

p60l51.text: identified   at   all   levels,   independently   of   existing   hierarchies.

p60l52.text: One of the key risk management tasks is to limit market price

p60l53.text: risks through the use of derivatives, among other things. The

p60l54.text: executive   board   has   defined   the   acceptable   instruments   in

p60l55.text: guidelines, which also govern hedging strategies, respon-

p60l56.text: sibilities, processes and control mechanisms. The hedging

p60l57.text: instruments are used to hedge operating activities and are

p60l58.text: entered into on regulated markets or with banks that have a

p61l7.text: System for the early detection of risks

p61l8.text: The executive board bears group-wide responsibility for the

p61l9.text: risk management system, for the early detection of existential

p61l10.text: threats to the company and strategic risks and also for initi-

p61l11.text: ating countermeasures. It has set up a risk committee, which

p61l12.text: comprises the executive board and managers from the pro-

p61l13.text: curement, sales, logistics, production, business development,

p61l14.text: public   relations,   finance,   accounting   and   controlling   divisions

p61l15.text: and   Südzucker   risk   management.   The   risk   committee   usually

p61l16.text: convenes once a month and also on an ad hoc basis if and

p61l17.text: when the need arises. The subject of the consultations includes

p61l18.text: all risk categories. For the main risks relating to raw materials

p61l19.text: sourcing,   sales,   trading   and   financial   market   risks,   standard-

p61l20.text: ised scenario projections are calculated on the basis of future

p61l21.text: market expectations and the effects on planned operating

p61l22.text: profit   are   determined.   Risk   is   assessed   on   a   monthly   basis   for

p61l23.text: the   current   and   following   financial   year.   The   results   obtained

p61l24.text: by the risk committee are documented on a monthly basis.

p61l25.text: Any trading risks that exist are assessed on a daily basis. In

p61l26.text: addition to the regular reporting, ad hoc risks require inter-

p61l27.text: nal group reporting to the executive board. The independent

p61l28.text: auditor regularly assesses whether the system for the early

p61l31.text: An effective risk management system requires open and

p61l32.text: prompt communication with the employees within the ­

p61l33.text: company and responsible action on the part of the employ-

p61l34.text: ees. Partly through its direct involvement in the risk commit-

p61l35.text: tee, management ensures that this open and prompt com-

p61l36.text: munication takes place and requires that the employees deal

p61l37.text: with risks in an active and conscious manner. Operational and

p61l38.text: strategic risks are reported on a regular basis as part of the

p61l39.text: overall planning, controlling and reporting process.

p61l41.text: CropEnergies documents all material corporate risks in an inter-

p61l42.text: nal risk register. A risk owner who is responsible for assess-

p61l43.text: ing and estimating the risk is assigned to every risk. The risk

p61l44.text: owner   uses   defined   early   warning   indicators   to   monitor   the

p61l45.text: risk in question, taking corresponding countermeasures based

p61l46.text: on a decision taken by the risk committee or in consultation

p61l47.text: with the responsible member of the executive board. In addi-

p61l48.text: tion, the risk owner makes an assessment of the probability

p61l49.text: of occurrence of the risk in question and its short-term and

p61l50.text: mid-term   financial   impact   on   the   result   of   operating   activities.

p61l51.text: The risk register is updated at regular intervals and, where

p61l52.text: necessary, has newly occurred risks added to it.

p61l54.text: The   Südzucker   Group’s   internal   audit   department   examines   and

p61l55.text: assesses the cost-effectiveness and regularity of the ­business

p61l56.text: processes at CropEnergies. It also monitors the effectiveness of

p61l57.text: the internal control systems and the risk management system.

p63l42.text: The United Kingdom’s expected exit from the European Union

p63l43.text: (Brexit) may entail risks for CropEnergies’ business activity

p63l44.text: which it is currently not possible to estimate. After the negoti-

p63l45.text: ations about the terms of the withdrawal proceeded slowly at

p63l48.text: of the United Kingdom. However, this agreement cannot

p63l49.text: enter into force until it commands a majority in the House of

p63l74.text: To produce ethanol, the CropEnergies Group mainly requires

p63l75.text: raw materials containing carbohydrates. The availability of such

p63l76.text: raw   materials   is   subject   to   fluctuations   in   harvest   yields   that

p63l77.text: may increase in their frequency and intensity due to extreme

p63l78.text: weather   events.   Price   fluctuations   on   the   world   markets   for

p63l79.text: agricultural commodities and foreign exchange markets have

p63l80.text: a direct impact on CropEnergies’ raw material costs.

p63l81.text: CropEnergies reduces the raw materials price risk associated

p63l82.text: with producing ethanol to some extent by revenues from the

p63l83.text: sale of food and animal feed products generated in the produc-

p64l2.text: tion process. Since changes in grain prices are usually accom-

p64l3.text: panied by a change in the prices of high-grade food and ani-

p64l4.text: mal feed products in the same direction, CropEnergies can

p64l5.text: partly   offset   price   fluctuations   in   the   raw   materials   purchased

p64l6.text: through revenues from the sale of these products ("natural

p64l7.text: hedge"). CropEnergies therefore bases its risk assessment

p64l8.text: on a balanced appraisal of the raw material costs and the

p64l9.text: proceeds from high-grade food and animal feed products

p64l10.text: ("steering according to net raw material costs"). In addition,

p64l11.text: CropEnergies can reduce the impact of a possible rise in grain

p64l12.text: prices on raw material costs through a far-sighted procure-

p64l13.text: ment policy. In doing so, CropEnergies’ objective is to secure

p64l14.text: the raw materials required for its delivery commitments in

p66l53.text: an integral part of the corporate planning process. Thanks to

p66l55.text: on ample cash resources in the short term where necessary.

p69l32.text: and divestments, the rules of procedure of both the execu-

p69l33.text: tive board and the supervisory board stipulate that decisions

p69l34.text: are subject to approval by the supervisory board. The exec-

p69l35.text: utive board keeps the supervisory board regularly, promptly

p69l36.text: and extensively informed in writing as well as at its regular

p69l37.text: meetings about the planning and development of the busi-

p69l38.text: ness operations, and the position of the group including risk

p69l40.text: The chairman of the supervisory board coordinates the activ-

p69l41.text: ities of the supervisory board, conducts its meetings and rep-

p69l42.text: resents the interests of the supervisory board externally. The

p69l43.text: supervisory board convenes without the executive board if

p69l44.text: necessary.   In   the   case   of   significant   events,   an   extraordinary

p69l45.text: meeting of the supervisory board is convened where neces-

p69l46.text: sary. In order to discharge its duties, the supervisory board

p69l47.text: can summon auditors, legal consultants and other internal

p69l48.text: and external consultants at its own discretion. The supervisory

p69l49.text: board passes resolutions on the structure of the compensation

p69l50.text: system for the executive board together with the key contrac-

p69l51.text: tual components and reviews it on a regular basis. The super-

p69l52.text: visory board has drawn up its own rules of procedure for its

p69l53.text: work;   these   are   in   force,   as   amended   on   13   November   2017.

p69l55.text: The supervisory board of CropEnergies AG, which comprises

p69l56.text: six members, is solely composed of shareholder represent-

p69l57.text: atives pursuant to § 96 (1) and § 101 (1) AktG. Each term of

p69l58.text: office   of   the   shareholder   representatives   newly   elected   by   the

p69l59.text: annual general meeting on 18 July 2017 runs for the period

p69l60.text: until adjournment of the annual general meeting that decides

p69l61.text: on   approval   for   the   2021/22   financial   year   (i.e.,   until   the   annual

p69l62.text: general meeting in 2022). All members of the supervisory board

p69l63.text: are familiar with the sector in which CropEnergies operates.

p69l64.text: Franz-Josef   Möllenberg   is   the   financial   expert   on   the   supervi-

p69l65.text: sory board and the audit committee, i.e., a member who has

p69l66.text: expertise in the areas of accounting and auditing.

p69l67.text: *  The following declaration on corporate management and the corporate governance report

p69l68.text: have not been checked by an auditor, with the exception of the compensation report.

p70l3.text: Regarding its composition, the supervisory board is particu-

p70l9.text: ■   Every member of the supervisory board should have ade-

p70l10.text: quate entrepreneurial and/or company experience and

p70l11.text: ensure   that   sufficient   time   is   available   to   carry   out   duties

p70l13.text: ■   Every member of the supervisory board should have the

p70l14.text: reliability and personal integrity required to perform the

p70l16.text: ■   At least two members of the supervisory board should be

p70l17.text: “independent” within the meaning of paragraph 5.4.2 of the

p70l19.text: ■   The supervisory board should not have more than two for-

p70l21.text: ■   The supervisory board should have at least two members

p70l24.text: ■   At least one member of the supervisory board should have

p71l41.text: The conscientious handling of business risks is one of the prin-

p71l42.text: ciples of good corporate governance. Group-wide and compa-

p71l43.text: ny-specific   reporting   and   control   systems   are   available   to   the

p71l44.text: executive board and management of CropEnergies, enabling

p71l45.text: them to identify, analyse and manage these risks. The sys-

p71l46.text: tems are continuously further developed, and adjusted to the

p71l47.text: changing framework conditions. The executive board keeps

p71l48.text: the supervisory board regularly informed about current risks

p71l49.text: and their development. The audit committee is especially con-

p71l50.text: cerned   with   monitoring   the   financial   reporting   process,   the

p71l51.text: effectiveness of the internal control system, risk management

p71l52.text: and the internal auditing system as well as the auditing of the

p71l53.text: financial   statements.   Risk   management   at   CropEnergies   is   out-

p71l54.text: lined in the risk and opportunities report on pages 58 – 66.

p72l3.text: Good corporate governance implies the responsible manage-

p72l4.text: ment and control of corporate enterprises oriented towards

p72l5.text: long-term value creation. The aim of corporate governance is

p72l6.text: to   promote   the   trust   of   shareholders   and   investors,   the   finan-

p72l7.text: cial markets, business partners, employees and the general

p72l8.text: public in the company, thereby also increasing the value of

p72l9.text: the company on a sustainable, long-term basis. The executive

p72l10.text: and supervisory boards of CropEnergies AG are committed to

p72l11.text: the principles of good corporate governance. CropEnergies ful-

p72l12.text: fils   the   most   stringent   transparency   requirements   on   German

p72l13.text: stock exchanges. Accordingly, the CropEnergies share has been

p72l14.text: listed in the Prime Standard since 2006. Compliance with the

p72l15.text: German Corporate Governance Code underlines the commit-

p74l53.text: For CropEnergies, compliance, in other words adherence to

p74l54.text: statutory provisions and company-internal directives, is the

p74l55.text: basis of good corporate management. Its objective is to ensure

p74l56.text: the lawful conduct of the company, its corporate bodies and

p74l57.text: employees in respect of the obligations and prohibitions

p74l58.text: imposed by laws and rules. The aim is to protect employees

p74l59.text: from infringing or violating laws and rules, and to support

p74l60.text: them in applying legal requirements and company guidelines

p74l61.text: correctly   and   appropriately.   As   a   member   of   the   Südzucker

p74l62.text: Group, CropEnergies has adopted the latter’s code of con-

p74l63.text: duct and the compliance corporate values and principles con-

p74l64.text: tained therein in an appropriate form. The corporate stand-

p74l65.text: ards   existing   within   the   Südzucker   Group   have   been   codified

p74l66.text: in these principles. The objective is to ensure that the princi-

p74l67.text: ples are enforced throughout CropEnergies utilising the exist-

p74l68.text: ing   reporting   procedures   and   information   flows.

p74l69.text: Focuses of the compliance corporate values and principles

p74l70.text: that apply across the group are anti-trust law compliance, cor-

p74l71.text: ruption prevention, data protection, environmental protection

p74l72.text: and capital market compliance (especially insider rules and ad

p74l73.text: hoc disclosures). The integrity of employees and conformity

p74l74.text: with the law invariably form the basis for good compliance.

p75l2.text: Compliance business values and principles and code of

p75l4.text: CropEnergies aims to compete successfully through innova-

p75l5.text: tion, quality, reliability and fairness. This entails complying

p75l6.text: with internal rules, as well as statutory regulations. In addi-

p75l7.text: tion to group-wide directives, compliance in the company is

p75l8.text: enshrined in the code of conduct and in the compliance busi-

p75l9.text: ness values and principles. The compliance business values

p75l10.text: and principles highlight key issues that are very important in

p75l11.text: day-to-day practice. They are published on CropEnergies’ web-

p75l14.text: and the code of conduct at http://www.cropenergies.com/de/

p75l16.text: CropEnergies applies the laws currently in force and expects

p75l17.text: no less from its employees and business partners.

p75l18.text: The code of conduct and the compliance business values and

p75l19.text: principles are implemented in a manner that is standard across

p75l20.text: the group and binding on all subsidiaries.

p75l22.text: CropEnergies has incorporated the corporate standards exist-

p75l23.text: ing in the CropEnergies Group into its compliance management

p75l24.text: system and linked the various compliance-relevant depart-

p75l25.text: ments   and   fields   of   activity.   The   compliance   management   sys-

p75l26.text: tem and its principles of “knowledge” (informing and training),

p75l28.text: (reporting and acting) aim to ensure the lawful conduct of the

p75l29.text: company, its executive bodies and its employees.

p75l31.text: Employees are provided with the necessary information sources,

p75l32.text: training and advisory support to avoid breaching laws and

p75l33.text: rules. All superiors must organise their areas of responsibil-

p75l34.text: ity in such a way that compliance with the code of conduct,

p75l35.text: the compliance business values and principles, the in-house

p75l36.text: directives and the statutory regulations is guaranteed. After

p75l37.text: all, only risk-aware employees can recognise risks and suc-

p75l38.text: cessfully avoid or at least reduce them.

p75l40.text: the   prompt   flow   of   information.   They   are   responsible,   among

p75l41.text: other things, for training and the investigation of compli-

p75l47.text: immediately   to   the   Compliance   Officer,   the   compliance   de -

p76l44.text: Appointment and removal of executive board members

p76l45.text: Pursuant to § 84 and § 85 AktG, the members of the exec-

p76l46.text: utive board are appointed and/or removed by the supervi-

p76l47.text: sory board. Pursuant to § 6 (1) of the articles of association,

p76l48.text: the executive board must comprise at least two individuals.

p76l50.text: number of executive board members. The supervisory board

p76l51.text: can appoint a chairman as well as a deputy chairman to the

p76l53.text: appointed   for   a   term   of   five   years   in   each   case.

p90l44.text: In   preparing   the   consolidated   financial   statements   of   the   group   companies,   the   relevant   accounting   and   valuation   principles

p90l45.text: under IFRS must be applied uniformly to like transactions and other events in similar circumstances. Accounting and valua-

p90l46.text: tion principles are explained only if the relevant standards make provision for options in respect of accounting and valuation

p90l47.text: or   if   the   principles   are   further   specified.   In   particular,   there   is   no   repetition   of   the   texts   of   the   respective   standards   or   repro-

p90l49.text: Acquired goodwill is reported under intangible assets.   Goodwill   and   intangible   assets   with   an   indefinite   useful   life   are   not   amor-

p90l50.text: tised as scheduled, but are subjected to an impairment test (impairment-only approach) once every year and if there are indi-

p90l51.text: cations of impairment (triggering events). The procedure for this impairment test is presented in the balance sheet disclosures.

p90l52.text: Property, plant and equipment is valuated at acquisition or production cost, less straight-line depreciation and impairment.

p90l53.text: In the year of acquisition, the asset values of property, plant and equipment are written down on a pro rata temporis basis.

p90l54.text: Government grants and subsidies are deducted from acquisition cost.

p91l1.text: Notes   to   the   consolidated   financial   statements  |  89

p91l2.text: Property,   plant   and   equipment   and   intangible   assets   with   a   finite   useful   life   are   depreciated   as   scheduled   on   the   basis   of   the

p91l14.text: Inventories are measured at acquisition or production cost and, in the case of food and animal feed products, at net realisa-

p91l15.text: ble   value.   The   average   cost   method   or   the   FIFO   method   (first   in   –   first   out)   is   applied,   as   this   corresponds   to   the   actual   order

p91l16.text: in which the inventories are consumed. Production cost includes the production-related full costs measured on the basis of

p91l17.text: normal   capacity.   Specifically,   production   cost   includes   the   direct   costs   as   well   as   fixed   and   variable   production   overheads

p91l18.text: (material and manufacturing overhead costs) including depreciation on production facilities. Included in particular are the

p91l19.text: costs   incurred   at   the   specific   production   cost   centres.   Financing   costs   are   not   included.   If   necessary,   the   lower   realisable   net

p91l20.text: selling value less costs still to be incurred (net realisable value) is applied. This net realisable value is the estimated revenues

p91l21.text: realisable in the normal course of business from the sale of the product less the variable selling costs required to sell it. ­

p91l22.text: Write-downs   on   work   in   progress   and   finished   goods   are   reported   under   the   item   “Change   in   inventories“.   Write-downs   are

p91l23.text: reversed if and to the extent that the net realisable value of the previously impaired inventories increases.

p91l24.text: Trade receivables without   a   significant   financing   component   are   measured   at   their   transaction   price   upon   initial   recognition.

p91l25.text: The other financial assets are measured at their market value plus transaction costs at the time of accrual and subsequently

p91l26.text: at amortised acquisition costs on the basis of the effective interest method.

p91l27.text: Adequate   specific   valuation   allowances   are   recognised   on   separate   impairment   accounts   for   default   and   other   risks   asso-

p91l28.text: ciated with the receivables. The nominal values less necessary valuation allowances thereby correspond to the fair values.

p91l29.text: Unrecoverable   receivables   are   derecognised   on   a   case-by-case   basis.   With   the   introduction   of   IFRS   9   value   allowances   for   trade

p91l30.text: receivables not only include single asset value allowances for registered credit risks, such as customer bankruptcy or default

p91l31.text: of more than 90 days without reliable information on collateral, but also provisions for impairment related to future expected

p91l32.text: credit defaults. Impairments accounting for expected future credit defaults are determined based on past credit default rates

p91l33.text: while considering the number of days payment of trade receivables is overdue.

p91l34.text: CO2 emission rights are recognised in accordance with IAS 38 (Intangible Assets), IAS 20 (Government Grants) and IAS 37

p91l35.text: (Provisions). CO2 emission rights allocated or acquired at no charge for each calendar year are intangible assets, which are
