p92l2.text: classified   as   other   current   assets.   They   are   measured   at   acquisition   cost,   which   is   zero   in   the   case   of   emission   rights   that   are

p92l4.text: If   actual   emissions   exceed   the   allocated   certificates,   a   provision   for   CO2

p92l5.text: emissions is recognised and expensed. The provision

p92l6.text: is   measured   on   the   basis   of   the   acquisition   cost   of   purchased   certificates   or   the   market   value   of   emission   certificates   on   the

p92l8.text: In   the   case   of   defined-benefit   pension   plans,   the   provisions for pensions and similar obligations are measured on the basis

p92l9.text: of   the   projected   unit   credit   method   according   to   IAS   19   (Employee   Benefits).   This   method   not   only   incorporates   the   pension

p92l10.text: benefits   and   the   accumulated   future   pension   benefits   known   as   of   the   reporting   date   but   also   takes   account   of   future   salary

p92l11.text: and pension adjustments. The calculation is based on actuarial valuations taking biometric data into account.

p92l12.text: Payments   for   defined-contribution   pension   plans   are   expensed   as   they   fall   due   and   are   reported   under   personnel   expenses.

p92l13.text: Payments   for   state   pension   plans   are   accounted   for   in   the   same   way   as   the   payments   for   defined-contribution   pension   plans.

p92l14.text: The group has no other payment obligations beyond the payment of the contributions.

p92l15.text: Other provisions also cover risks arising from legal disputes and proceedings if the probability of occurrence is more than

p92l16.text: 50% and reliable estimation is possible. In order to determine or estimate the amount of provisions, use is made of the

p92l17.text: claims applicable in the individual case, the assessment of the facts as well as the results of similar processes and indepen-

p92l19.text: Reported income taxes comprise taxes levied on taxable income in the individual countries and changes to deferred tax assets

p92l20.text: and liabilities. Current income taxes are reported as the amount of tax expected to be paid or reimbursed based on the statu-

p92l21.text: tory provisions that are applicable or have been adopted on the reporting date. Initial and subsequent measurement take place

p92l22.text: completely   in   the   tax   expense.   The   income   tax   liabilities   from   the   past   financial   year   are   reported   under   current   tax   liabilities

p92l23.text: and receivables from advance payments under current tax assets. Non-current tax liabilities mainly comprise income tax for

p92l24.text: prior-year periods that have not yet been conclusively audited. The compounding or discounting of tax liabilities is recognised

p92l25.text: in the income statement in the item “Taxes on income“. Tax items that may still change, due, for example, to tax audits, have

p92l26.text: been estimated on the basis of the expected tax payment or refund.

p92l27.text: Deferred taxes are calculated on temporary differences in the values of assets and liabilities between IFRS and the tax accoun-

p92l28.text: ting as well as on loss carry-forwards to the extent that they can be used for tax purposes. Deferred tax assets and deferred

p92l29.text: tax liabilities are reported as separate items. Deferred tax claims are set off against deferred tax obligations if the income

p92l30.text: taxes are levied by the same tax authority and there is a legally enforceable right to set-off. A resulting excess of deferred tax

p92l31.text: assets is recognised only to the extent that taxable income is likely to be available, against which deferred taxes can be offset.

p92l32.text: Assessment   of   the   recoverability   of   deferred   tax   assets   is   subject   to   company-specific   forecasts   about,   among   other   things,

p92l33.text: the future earnings situation of the group company in question.

p93l1.text: Notes   to   the   consolidated   financial   statements  |  91

p93l2.text: Deferred tax liabilities that arise as a result of temporary differences in connection with investments in subsidiaries and

p93l3.text: entities consolidated at equity are recognised unless the timing of the reversal of the temporary differences can be con­-

p93l4.text: trolled   by   the   group   and   the   temporary   differences   are   unlikely   to   reverse   as   a   result   of   this   controlling   influence   within   the

p93l6.text: Deferred taxes were calculated in accordance with IAS 12 (Income Taxes), taking into account the respective national income

p93l7.text: tax rates that are applicable or have been substantially enacted as of the balance sheet date and that are expected to apply

p93l8.text: when the related deferred tax asset is realised or the deferred tax liability settled. Deferred tax assets and liabilities associa-

p93l9.text: ted with income and expenses recognised in shareholders’ equity are treated identically.

p93l10.text: Trade payables and other financial liabilities are recognised, on initial measurement, at their market value less transaction

p93l11.text: costs and subsequently at amortised acquisition cost on the basis of the effective interest method.

p93l12.text: Financial assets   are   subdivided   into   the   following   categories:   a)   “financial   assets   measured   at   fair   value”   and   b)   “at

p93l13.text: amortised costs“. Financial liabilities are   classified   upon   initial   recognition   in   the   categories:   a)   “at   amortised   cost”   and

p93l14.text: b)   “financial   liabilities   recognised   at   fair   value“.

p93l15.text: The   classification   depends   on   the   purpose   for   which   the   financial   assets   were   acquired.   Management   determines   the

p93l16.text: classification   of   the   financial   assets   upon   their   initial   recognition   and   reviews   the   classification   at   each   reporting   date.

p93l17.text: Similarly   to   the   procedure   for   financial   assets,   the   classification   of   financial   liabilities   also   depends   on   their   respective

p93l18.text: purpose. Recognition is carried out at day of trading.

p93l19.text: Derivative financial instruments are recognised as assets or liabilities and, irrespective of their purpose, measured at fair

p93l20.text: value.   Recognition   takes   place   as   of   the   day   of   trading.   Changes   in   fair   value   are   recognised   through   profit   or   loss   unless   there

p93l21.text: is   a   hedge   accounting   relationship   between   the   derivative   financial   instruments   and   the   hedged   item.   In   this   case,   recognition

p93l22.text: of   changes   in   the   fair   value   depends   on   the   type   of   hedging   relationship.   Derivative   financial   instruments   for   hedging   price

p93l23.text: risks which are not designated in a hedge accounting relationship are presented under derivatives held for trading. In the case

p93l24.text: of derivatives held for trading, changes in the fair values of the hedging transactions are recognised in the income statement.

p93l25.text: Cash   flow   hedge   derivatives   are   used   to   hedge   the   risk   of   fluctuation   in   the   future   cash   flows   associated   with   a   recognised

p93l26.text: asset,   a   reported   debt   or   a   planned   transaction   that   has   a   high   probability   of   occurring.   If   a   cash   flow   hedge   derivative   exists,

p93l27.text: the unrealised gains and losses of the hedging transaction are initially recognised under other comprehensive income. They

p93l28.text: are   not   included   in   the   income   statement   until   the   hedged   item   is   recognised   through   profit   or   loss.

p93l29.text: As   the   derivative   financial   instruments   used   are   mainly   forward   transactions   traded   on   the   stock   exchange,   corresponding

p93l30.text: collateral needs to be deposited for them. The forward transactions and the collateral are recognised gross on the balance

p94l1.text: 92  |  Notes   to   the   consolidated   financial   statements

p94l2.text: sheet.   Initial   margins   to   be   paid   are   recognised   under   “Other   assets“.   Variation   margins   to   be   paid   or   received   during   the   term

p94l3.text: of   the   derivative   financial   instruments   are   recognised   under   “Other   assets”   or   “Other   liabilities“.   The   utilisation   of   the   credit

p94l4.text: line made available for this is recognised under “Liabilities to banks“.

p94l5.text: If   a   service   has   been   fulfilled,   revenues are recognised with the transaction prices assigned to the service. Revenues are repor-

p94l6.text: ted without rebates and discounts, without turnover tax and after eliminating intra-group sales. Revenues are recognised once

p94l7.text: the client has assumed control of the asset.

p94l8.text: Discretionary decisions have to be taken when applying the accounting policies. This applies especially with regard to the

p94l9.text: following issues: a decision needs to be made as to whether to treat certain contracts as derivatives or to account for them as

p94l10.text: so-called in-house consumption contracts from executory contracts.

p94l11.text: The   preparation   of   the   consolidated   financial   statements   according   to   IFRS   requires   assumptions and estimations to be

p94l12.text: made. These assessments by management can affect the value of the assets and liabilities reported as well as income and

p94l13.text: expenses, and the recognition of contingent liabilities.

p94l14.text: In the case of provisions for pensions and similar obligations, the discount rate assumed is also an important variable. The

p94l15.text: discount   rate   for   pension   obligations   is   determined   on   the   basis   of   the   yields   of   prime   fixed-rate   industrial   bonds   observable

p94l16.text: on   the   financial   markets   as   of   the   reporting   date.   Analytically   derived   assumptions   are   also   made   about   pensionable   age,   life

p94l17.text: expectancy,   staff   turnover,   and   future   salary   and   pension   increases.   With   regard   to   the   impact   of   changes   to   individual   actua-

p94l18.text: rial   assumptions   on   the   amount   of   defined-benefit   pension   obligations,   reference   is   made   to   the   disclosures   on   the   sensiti-

p94l19.text: vity analysis under item (22) “Provisions for pensions and similar obligations“. Assumptions and estimations also relate to the

p94l20.text: recognition and measurement of other provisions.

p94l21.text: The   assessment   of   goodwill   impairments   and   the   production   plant   in   Wilton   is   based   on   future   cash   flow   forecasts   and   the

p94l22.text: application   of   a   discount   rate   that   is   adjusted   to   the   industry   and   the   company-specific   risk.

p94l24.text: planning, with the prices for ethanol and grain being particularly volatile.

p101l42.text: The focus of the research and development activities carried out by the CropEnergies Group was on technological support for

p101l43.text: processes in existing production facilities, their optimisation and further improvements in food and animal feed products.

p101l44.text: In addition, a contribution was made to the shaping of standards, new concepts for the production of ethanol were developed

p101l45.text: and analytical methods with regard to the production of neutral alcohol implemented.

p102l4.text: The   goodwill   resulting   from   the   first-time   consolidation   of   acquisitions   reported   under   intangible   assets   is   not   amortised   as

p102l5.text: scheduled.   Concessions,   commercial   IP   and   similar   rights   mainly   consist   of   acquired   software   that   has   a   finite   useful   life.

p103l2.text: When   carrying   out   impairment   tests,   goodwill   must   be   allocated   to   cash-generating   units   (CGUs)   or   groups   of   cash-genera-

p103l3.text: ting units. As part of impairment tests, the corresponding book values of the CGUs are regularly compared with their value in

p103l4.text: use (guiding value concept at CropEnergies) in order to identify a possible impairment.

p103l5.text: CropEnergies   has   defined   its   CGUs   in   accordance   with   internal   reporting.   In   the   CropEnergies   Group,   the   only   CGU   bearing

p103l6.text: goodwill is Ryssen France (including the companies Ryssen und COFA). The goodwill amounts to € 6.1 (6.1) million.

p103l7.text: To   determine   the   recoverable   amount,   CropEnergies   first   calculates   the   value   in   use.   The   value   in   use   is   the   present   value

p103l8.text: of   the   future   cash   flows   that   can   probably   be   produced   from   a   cash-generating   unit.   The   value   in   use   is   determined   on   the

p103l9.text: basis   of   a   going   concern   valuation   model   (discounted   cash   flow   method).   Cash   flow   forecasts   based   on   the   5-year   planning

p103l10.text: approved by the executive board or passed by the supervisory board and valid at the time of conducting the impairment test

p103l11.text: are used for this purpose. The planning is based on experience as well as expectations regarding macroeconomic framework

p103l12.text: data and market developments, particularly in respect of ethanol.

p103l13.text: The cost of capital has to be calculated as the weighted average of the cost of equity and the cost of borrowing. The cost of

p103l14.text: equity   is   derived   from   the   returns   expected   by   CropEnergies’   shareholders;   the   borrowing   costs   used   are   derived   from   the

p103l15.text: long-term   refinancing   conditions   of   CropEnergies’   capital   market   environment.   As   of   31   August   2018,   the   correspondingly

p103l16.text: determined discount rate was 7.9% (7.8%) before taxes and 5.7% (5.7%) after taxes.

p103l17.text: For   the   extrapolation   of   cash   flows   beyond   the   planning   period   in   the   CGUs,   CropEnergies   uses   a   constant   growth   rate   of   1.5%

p103l18.text: (1.5%). This growth rate for discounting the perpetuity is below the growth rate calculated in the detailed planning period and

p103l19.text: serves   largely   to   compensate   a   general   inflation   rate.   The   cash   flows   are   calculated   less   the   capital   expenditures   required   to

p103l20.text: achieve the assumed corporate development. These reinvestment rates are based on past experience regarding the need for

p103l21.text: replacement purchases of property, plant and equipment.

p108l8.text: In   the   context   of   defined-contribution   pension   plans,   CropEnergies   pays   into   state   or   private   pension   insurance   schemes   on

p108l9.text: the basis of statutory regulations, contractual agreements or on a voluntary basis. The current premium payments are repor-

p108l10.text: ted as expense under personnel expenses. They amounted to € 1.9 (2.4) million within the group. By paying the contributions,

p108l11.text: the   company   has   no   further   payment   obligations;   no   provision   is   therefore   recognised.

p108l13.text: The   company   pension   scheme   at   CropEnergies   is   mainly   based   on   direct   defined-benefit   commitments.   As   a   general   rule,   the

p108l14.text: pensions are calculated on the basis of the time served with the company and the relevant salary or wage base. Obligations

p108l15.text: similar to pensions exist at French companies. They are measured in accordance with actuarial principles, taking the future

p108l18.text: provisions   and   the   partly   or   wholly   funded   future   defined-benefit   obligations   less   the   fair   value   of   the   plan   assets.

p114l3.text: The primary investment objective for the plan assets is to provide full coverage of the payment obligations resulting from the

p114l8.text: The   CropEnergies   Group   is   exposed   to   various   risks   in   connection   with   defined-benefit   pension   plans.   In   addition   to   general

p114l9.text: actuarial risks such as interest rate risk, there are risks associated with divergence from actuarial assumptions, such as wage

p114l10.text: and salary trends, pension trends, pension age, chronological age and staff turnover. There are capital market risks or credit

p114l11.text: rating   and   investment   risks   associated   with   plan   assets.   Further   risks   exist   owing   to   changes   in   inflation   rates.

p114l12.text: The return on plan assets is assumed to be at the level of the discount rate. If the actual return on plan assets is below the

p114l13.text: discount   rate   applied,   the   net   obligation   from   the   pension   plans   increases.   The   net   obligation   level   is   significantly   affected   by

p114l14.text: the discount rate, with the currently low interest rate level entailing a relatively high obligation. A decline in returns from cor-

p114l15.text: porate   bonds   would   result   in   a   further   increase   in   defined-benefit   obligations,   which   could   be   offset   only   to   a   limited   extent

p114l16.text: by a positive development in the market values of the corporate bonds contained in the plan assets.

p114l17.text: Possible   inflation   risks,   which   may   result   in   an   increase   in   defined-benefit   obligations,   exist   indirectly   with   a   salary   rise   due   to

p114l18.text: inflation   in   the   active   phase   as   well   as   with   pension   adjustments   due   to   inflation.

p116l15.text: The   net   financial   position   as   of   28   February   2019   shows   net   financial   assets   of   €   36.8   (36.9)   million.   The   net   financial   assets

p116l18.text: On the balance sheet date, no encumbrances or other liens were assigned to creditors.

p116l20.text: Capital management within the CropEnergies Group comprises control of cash, equity and debt positions. CropEnergies’ aim

p116l21.text: is a balance sheet structure with a high level of equity, which secures the company’s growth strategy, taking reasonable capi-

p116l22.text: tal costs into account and with above-average creditworthiness.

p116l23.text: The   CropEnergies   Group’s   financing   is   based   on   the   ability   to   generate   consistently   positive   cash   flows,   stable   relations   with

p116l24.text: the shareholder groups backing the company, access to the capital markets and reliable banking relationships. The communi-

p116l25.text: cation   with   capital   market   participants   pursues   a   policy   of   financial   transparency   based   on   a   reporting   system   which   defines

p116l26.text: both the corporate planning and the reporting processes, using the same valuation and disclosure principles.

p116l27.text: If necessary, CropEnergies avails itself of a borrowing structure optimised in terms of maturity and interest terms. For interim

p116l28.text: funding,   flexible   access   to   short-term   liquidity   is   an   important   element   of   the   financing   structure.

p116l29.text: CropEnergies   pursues   a   conservative   financing   policy   aimed   at   safeguarding   the   profitability,   liquidity   and   stability   of   the

p116l30.text: company,   which   is   flanked   by   strict   financial   management   (cash   and   liquidity   management)   and   integrated   risk   management.

p116l31.text: The   financing   policy   is   based   on   the   following   objectives:

p116l32.text: ■ a strong capital structure with a sustainable equity funding base through the shareholder groups backing the company,

p116l33.text: ■ debt   funding   instruments   that   allow   flexible   utilisation   while   assuring   a   balanced   maturity   profile,

p116l34.text: ■ access   to   sufficient   short-term   liquidity   at   all   times   and

p116l35.text: ■ controlling   of   financial   risks   through   integrated   risk   management.

p117l2.text: The management of the capital structure takes place on a long-term basis, focusing on both dynamic and static indicators.

p117l3.text: The   key   parameters   here   are   the   debt   ratio   (ratio   of   net   financial   debt   to   cash   flow),   the   debt   to   equity   ratio   (net   financial   debt

p117l4.text: as a percentage of equity) and the equity ratio (equity as a percentage of total assets).

p117l19.text: a) Use of derivative financial instruments

p117l20.text: The CropEnergies Group uses derivative instruments to a limited extent to hedge risks arising from its operating business. The

p117l21.text: use of these instruments is regulated within the framework of the risk management system by internal guidelines that set

p117l22.text: limits   based   on   the   hedged   items,   define   authorisation   procedures,   restrict   the   use   of   derivative   instruments   for   speculative

p117l23.text: purposes, minimise credit risks, and regulate the internal reporting and the separation of functions. Compliance with these

p117l24.text: guidelines and the due and proper execution and valuation of the transactions are regularly supervised, whereby it is ensured

p117l25.text: that the respective functions are strictly separated.

p117l26.text: Currency risks can   arise   both   from   operating   activities   and   from   foreign   currency   financing   outside   or   within   the   group.   Deri-

p117l27.text: vative hedging instruments are used to a limited extent to cover these risks. Raw materials were largely sourced, and pro-

p117l29.text: Interest rate risks   mainly   relate   to   financial   liabilities.   To   the   extent   that   interest   rate   risks   cannot   be   excluded   through   fixed-rate

p117l30.text: arrangements,   CropEnergies   has   the   option   to   use   derivative   hedging   instruments   to   counter   the   risk   of   fluctuating   interest   rates.

p117l31.text: Raw material price risks can   arise   mainly   in   connection   with   the   procurement   of   commodities   such   as   grain.   Where   price   risks

p117l32.text: cannot   be   excluded   through   physical   supply   contracts,   CropEnergies   uses   derivative   financial   instruments,   such   as   wheat

p117l33.text: futures and options, where possible and expedient, to limit these risks.

p117l34.text: Product price risks   can   arise   as   a   result   of   fluctuating   ethanol   prices.   CropEnergies   uses   derivative   hedges   to   hedge   price   change

p117l35.text: risks   in   respect   of   supply   agreements   with   fluctuating   ethanol   prices.

p118l2.text: b) Market values of derivative financial instruments

p118l3.text: The nominal values, market values and credit risks of the derivative instruments within the CropEnergies Group are as follows:

p118l35.text: All derivatives have maturities of less than one year.

p118l36.text: The nominal value of a derivative hedge is the arithmetical base on which payments are calculated. The hedged item and risk

p118l37.text: are not the nominal value, only the changes in price or interest rate based thereon.

p118l38.text: Market value represents the amount that CropEnergies would have to pay or receive if the hedge were liquidated on the

p118l39.text: reporting   date.   As   only   marketable,   tradable   financial   instruments   are   used   to   hedge   price   risks   related   to   grain   purchases

p118l40.text: and ethanol sales, the market value is determined on the basis of market quotations.

p123l2.text: (29)  Risk management in the CropEnergies Group

p123l3.text: The CropEnergies Group is exposed to market price risks arising from changes in end product, raw material and energy prices.

p123l4.text: In   addition,   there   are   financial   risks   such   as   currency,   interest   rate,   credit   and   liquidity   risks.

p123l5.text: Credit risks I The CropEnergies Group’s trade receivables are mostly in relation to customers in the oil, food and animal

p123l6.text: feed industries. The resulting credit risk is limited through credit sale insurance to 10% of the respective total outstanding

p123l7.text: receivables and is controlled on the basis of internal guidelines and limits.

p123l8.text: Valuation   allowances   based   on   the   actual   default   risk   are   recognised   where   necessary   for   any   remaining   risk   in   respect   of

p123l9.text: trade receivables. In accordance with internal group requirements, an allowance account is used, in principle, to adjust the

p123l10.text: carrying amounts of receivables. The maximum risk position arising from trade receivables corresponds to the book value

p123l11.text: of these receivables. The book values of past-due trade receivables and the residual doubtful trade receivables are stated in

p123l13.text: The maximum credit risk of other receivables and assets corresponds to the book value of these instruments and, in the assess-

p123l14.text: ment   of   CropEnergies,   is   not   significant.

p123l15.text: Liquidity risk I Liquidity   risk   denotes   the   risk   that   an   enterprise   may   not   be   able   to   meet   its   financial   obligations   on   time   or

p123l16.text: sufficiently.   The   liquidity   of   the   CropEnergies   Group   is   monitored   on   a   daily   basis   and   optimised   by   means   of   national   or   trans-

p123l18.text: The CropEnergies Group generates liquidity from its operating business and – where necessary – through recourse to exter-

p123l19.text: nal   finance.   The   funds   serve   to   finance   investments,   acquisitions   and   working   capital.

p123l20.text: Additionally,   to   assure   the   CropEnergies   Group’s   solvency   at   all   times   and   to   increase   its   financial   flexibility,   a   liquidity   reserve

p123l21.text: is maintained in the form of cash and cash equivalents but especially in the form of free credit lines.

p123l22.text: CropEnergies   AG   has   direct   and   flexible   access,   with   a   sub-credit   line   of   €   100   million,   to   a   €   600   million   syndicated   bank

p123l23.text: credit   facility   arranged   by   Südzucker   AG.

p124l2.text: The   following   table   shows   the   maturities   of   the   liabilities   as   of   28   February.   All   cash   outflows   are   undiscounted.

p124l135.text: The   cash   outflows   for   the   discharge   of   liabilities   are   based   on   the   earliest   due   date.   Financial   liabilities   were   completely   reduced

p124l136.text: in   the   previous   year.   The   interest   payments   on   financial   instruments   with   variable   interest   rates   are   calculated   on   the   basis

p124l137.text: of the interest rates applicable as of the reporting date. A net settlement agreement exists for all derivative contracts apart

p125l2.text: Currency risk I Currency risks can arise from transactions in foreign currency and are hedged on a limited scale through

p125l3.text: derivative   instruments.   The   use   of   these   hedging   instruments   takes   place   within   defined   limits   and   rules,   and   is   subject   to

p125l4.text: a constant control process. Raw materials are largely sourced, and products largely sold, in euro and, to a small extent, in ­

p125l6.text: Where   financial   receivables   or   liabilities   are   denominated   in   foreign   currency,   they   are   exposed   to   the   risk   of   currency   depre-

p125l7.text: ciation   or   appreciation   until   they   are   discharged.   However,   the   volume   of   financial   receivables   and   liabilities   denominated   in

p125l8.text: foreign currencies due to external companies is of minor importance for the CropEnergies Group.

p125l9.text: CropEnergies   can   however   also   be   exposed   to   indirect   currency   risks   from   fluctuations   in   the   market   value   of   the   euro   versus

p125l10.text: the US dollar and the Brazilian real. However, such indirect effects on the world market prices for raw materials, energy and

p125l12.text: Interest rate risk I CropEnergies is exposed to the risk of interest rate changes in the euro zone, with the interest rate risk

p125l13.text: relating   mainly   to   financial   liabilities.   As   at   28   February   2019,   CropEnergies   has   no   financial   liabilities.

p125l14.text: Market price risk I The CropEnergies Group is exposed to market price risks with regard to end products. CropEnergies cont-

p125l15.text: rols these risks through the arrangement of sales contracts and their term as well as through derivative instruments. The use

p125l16.text: of   these   hedging   instruments   takes   place   within   defined   limits   and   rules,   and   is   subject   to   a   comprehensive   control   process.

p126l6.text: in relation to the ethanol plants. The commitments for raw materials mostly relate to purchase orders for grain, raw alcohol

p126l7.text: and starch-based raw materials. There was a purchase order commitment of € 20.3 (15.8) million in relation to the compa-

p126l31.text: CropEnergies   may   be   liable   to   possible   obligations   arising   from   various   claims   or   proceedings   that   are   pending   or   could   be   filed.

p126l34.text: no   claims   or   proceedings   that   could   have   a   material   impact   on   the   CropEnergies   Group’s   financial   position.

p132l62.text: (41)  Report on events after the balance sheet date

p132l63.text: After   the   end   of   the   financial   year,   no   significant   changes   have   arisen   with   regard   to   the   economic   environment   or   the   situa-

p132l64.text: tion in our industry. There are no other events of particular importance to be reported for the CropEnergies Group.

p132l66.text: According to IFRS 8 (Operating Segments), information has to be disclosed on those segments that the company has

p132l67.text: created for internal reporting and control purposes (so-called management approach). The CropEnergies AG with its German

p132l68.text: subsidiaries and the foreign subsidiaries each form their own operating segment. In a second step, the operating segments

p132l69.text: are summarised into one segment subject to reporting in accordance with IFRS 8.12-14, as the CropEnergies Group produces

p132l70.text: only one homogeneous main product (ethanol). Similar end products that can be commercially distributed independently

p132l71.text: are produced in related or identical production processes. The planning and control of the CropEnergies Group’s operating

p137l6.text: In   our   view,   the   matter   of   most   significance   in   our   audit   was

p137l9.text: Our presentation of this key audit matter has been struc­

p137l14.text: Hereinafter we present the key audit matter:

p137l16.text: ➀   The companies of the CropEnergies Group use derivative

p137l17.text: financial   instruments.   These   include   in   particular   wheat

p137l18.text: futures for the purpose of hedging commodity price risks

p137l19.text: arising in the ordinary course of business. Commodities price

p137l20.text: risks result primarily from the procurement of agricultural

p137l21.text: commodities such as wheat, to the extent it is not possible

p137l22.text: to rule out risks of changing prices through the use of phy-

p137l23.text: sical settlement agreements. The total notional volume of

p137l24.text: outstanding wheat futures as of February 28, 2019 amount­-

p137l25.text: ed to EUR 45.8 million. The negative fair value of the deri-

p137l26.text: vative   financial   instruments   used   as   wheat   price   hedges

p137l27.text: amounts to EUR 1.7 million as of the balance sheet date. If

p137l28.text: the   financial   instruments   used   by   the   CropEnergies   Group

p137l29.text: are   effective   hedges   of   future   cash   flows   in   the   context   of

p137l30.text: hedge accounting in accordance with the requirements of

p137l31.text: IFRS 9, the effective portion of the changes in fair value

p137l32.text: are recognized directly in equity over the duration of the

p137l33.text: hedging relationship until the maturity of the hedged cash

p137l34.text: flows.   The   hedging   relationships   were   fully   effective   in   the

p137l35.text: fiscal   year,   so   that   no   ineffectiveness   was   recorded.

p137l36.text: In addition, wheat options are also used to hedge against

p137l37.text: commodity price risks that are not designated in an account­

p137l38.text: ing hedging relationship. These transactions were of minor

p137l39.text: significance   in   the   past   financial   year.

p137l40.text: On the ethanol market, purchase agreements are en­­-

p137l41.text: tered into with customers, with the sales price indexed to a

p137l42.text: variable ethanol price. The companies of the CropEnergies

p137l43.text: Group   have   therefore   concluded   derivative   financial   inst-

p137l44.text: ruments (ethanol futures) with a notional volume totaling

p137l45.text: EUR   38.0   million   to   hedge   against   price   fluctuations   arising

p137l46.text: from the sale of ethanol. The negative fair value of the deri-

p137l47.text: vative   financial   instruments   used   as   ethanol   price   hedges

p137l48.text: amounts to EUR 0.9 million are offset by positive fair values

p137l49.text: of € 0.4 million as of the balance sheet date. Given that the

p137l50.text: ethanol futures are designated as a hedging relationship,

p137l51.text: the   market   fluctuations   are   recognized   directly   in   equity.

p137l52.text: From our point of view, these matters were of particular

p137l53.text: significance   for   our   audit   due   to   the   high   complexity   and

p137l54.text: number of transactions as well as the extensive account­

p137l55.text: ing and reporting requirements under IFRS 9.

p137l56.text: ➁   As a part of our audit and together with the support of our

p137l57.text: internal specialists from Corporate Treasury Solutions, we,

p137l58.text: among other things, assessed the internal control system

p137l59.text: established by the Company in the area of the commodi-

p137l60.text: ties   derivatives   used.   We   obtained   bank   confirmations   in

p137l61.text: order to assess the completeness of and to examine the

p137l62.text: fair   values   of   the   outstanding   transactions.   We   verified   the

p137l63.text: market data used to determine the fair values on the basis

p137l64.text: of   external   sources.   We   assessed   the   hedge   documenta-

p137l65.text: tion and effectiveness tests, among other things, to verify

p138l1.text: that the requirements of IAS 39 for designation as a hedging

p138l2.text: relationship were duly met. In addition, we examined the

p138l3.text: hedge accounting, particularly in relation to the effects

p138l4.text: on   equity   and   earnings.   We   verified   that   the   conditions   for

p138l5.text: applying hedge accounting and the estimates and assump-

p138l6.text: tions   made   by   the   executive   directors   were   sufficiently   sub-

p138l7.text: stantiated and documented. A further component of the

p138l8.text: audit was the recognition in the balance sheet of derivative

p138l9.text: financial   instruments   not   designated   as   hedges.

p138l10.text: ➂   The Company‘s disclosures on the accounting treatment of

p138l11.text: hedging relationships are contained in sections (5) “Accoun-

p138l12.text: ting principles“, (20) “Trade receivables and other assets“,

p138l14.text: nal   disclosures   on   financial   instruments”   of   the   notes   to

p142l9.text: ➔ Biofuels.   The   aim   of   the   regulation   is   to   ensure   that   only

p142l10.text: ➔ Biofuels   produced   in   conformity   with   mandatory   sus-

p142l11.text: tainability   standards   benefit   from   tax   incentives   or   can   be

p142l12.text: c­ redited to the biofuel targets. The regulation implements

p142l13.text: the ➔ Sustainability   criteria   of   the   European   Union   for   the

p142l15.text: Blending (with petrol) I   Adding ➔ Ethanol   to   petrol.   In   Europe,

p142l16.text: the   standard   concerning   petrol   is   the   EN 228 standard   that   has

p142l17.text: allowed   the   addition   of   10 vol.-%   ➔ Ethanol   or   22 vol.-%   ETBE

p142l18.text: since the end of 2012. Different ethanol blending rates apply

p142l19.text: around   the   world   for   conventional   petrol   (e.g.,   18 – 27.5 vol.-%

p142l20.text: in   Brazil;   10 – 15 vol.-%   in   the   USA).

p142l21.text: Carbon dioxide (CO2) I   End product of the burning of any

p142l22.text: c ­ arbon-containing material and base product for the ­creation

p142l23.text: of   vegetable   biomass   through   photosynthesis.   When   biomass

p142l24.text: is burned, only the amount of CO2

p142l27.text: is the principal ➔ Greenhouse   gas.   CO2

p142l28.text: can be used in the food and packaging industries.

p142l29.text: CDS (Concentrated Distillers’ Solubles) I   Liquid animal

p142l30.text: feed from ➔ Stillage   which   is   produced   in   the   production   of

p142l31.text: ➔ Ethanol   from   grain   and   is   then   thickened.

p142l32.text: Cellulose I   Structural substance of plants, main component

p142l33.text: of cell walls. Cellulose is a polysaccharide consisting of ­several

p142l34.text: thousand ß-glucose components. It can be broken down by

p142l35.text: mineral   acids,   enzymes   or   fungi   (“wood   saccharification”,

p142l36.text: “wood alcohol production”). Processes for the production of

p142l37.text: ➔ Ethanol   from   cellulose   are   currently   under   development.

p142l39.text: D&O Insurance (Directors and Officers Insurance, also

p142l40.text: Board or Senior Officer Liability Insurance) I   Liability

p142l41.text: insurance which a company takes out to protect its boards and

p142l42.text: senior   officers   against   claims   for   damages   for   financial   losses.

p142l43.text: DDGS (Distillers’ Dried Grains with Solubles) I   Dry ­stillage.

p142l44.text: DDGS is the dried ➔ Stillage   produced   in   the   production   of

p142l45.text: e­ thanol from grains and is used as a valuable protein ­animal feed.

p142l46.text: Dehydration I   Term used for the so-called “drying” of ➔ Alcohol.

p142l47.text: In this last step of ➔ Ethanol   production,   virtually   all   the   re­

p142l48.text: maining water is removed from the ➔ Alcohol,   thus   achieving

p142l50.text: Distillation I   Separation of liquids which consist of different

p142l51.text: ingredients by means of controlled heating, e.g., fractional

p142l52.text: di ­ stillation of crude oil (petroleum) or separation of ➔ Alcohol

p142l53.text: and water. This separation process is based on the various

p142l54.text: boiling points of the compound ingredients.

p142l55.text: E5 I   Fuel   for   petrol   engines   with   up   to   5 vol.-%   ➔ Ethanol.

p142l56.text: E10 I   Fuel   for   petrol   engines   with   up   to   10 vol.-%   ➔ Ethanol.

p142l57.text: E20 I   Fuel   for   petrol   engines   with   up   to   20 vol.-%   ➔ Ethanol.

p142l58.text: Most newer models could run on this fuel without any problems.

p142l59.text: E85 I   Fuel   for   flexible   fuel   vehicles   (➔ FFVs).   E85   is   an   etha-

p142l60.text: nol-petrol mixture with an ethanol content of approximately

p142l61.text: 85%. In Germany, it is regulated by the DIN 51625 standard.

p142l62.text: Enzyme I   Archaic: ferment. A biochemical catalyst that helps

p142l63.text: to break down or change a substrate without being consumed

p142l65.text: Ethanol I   Also known as bioethanol, ethyl alcohol. Belongs

p142l66.text: to the group of alcohols, and is synonymous with ➔ Alcohol

p142l67.text: in the ­narrower sense. Ethanol is the main product of alcohol

p142l68.text: ➔ Fermentation,   and   is   the   principal   component   of   spirits   and

p142l69.text: alcoholic beverages. Ethanol is used as a fuel additive and as

p142l70.text: a fuel on its own, but also in the chemical and pharmaceu­

p142l71.text: tical industry. CropEnergies produces E. from renewable raw

p142l72.text: materials. Raw materials can be biomass containing sugar,

p142l73.text: starch or cellulose. CropEnergies uses grains, sugar syrups,

p143l1.text: Fermentation I   Biotechnical procedure for manufacturing

p143l2.text: a   desired   product;   in   the   course   of   the   procedure,   organic

p143l3.text: m­ aterial is converted by microorganisms such as bacteria,

p143l4.text: fungi or unicellular organisms or their enzymes. During the

p143l5.text: production of ➔ Ethanol,   the   sugar   contained   in   the   mash   is

p143l7.text: Fraud I Fraud refers to any intentional action, acquiescence

p143l8.text: or omission for the purpose of personal enrichment that is

p143l9.text: likely to have a negative impact on company success or cause

p143l10.text: damage to third parties. CropEnergies’ compliance manage-

p143l11.text: ment and corporate principles stipulate that such cases must

p143l12.text: be prevented or detected and processed.

p143l13.text: Fuel Quality Directive I   European Parliament and ­Council

p143l14.text: D ­ irective 98/70/EC of 13 October 1998 which sets ­minimum

p143l15.text: standards   for   the   quality   and   labelling   of   the   quality   specifications

p143l16.text: of   fuels.   With   this   directive,   the   European   Parliament   and

p143l17.text: Council have adopted an amendment proposed by the Euro-

p143l18.text: pean Commission to reduce air pollution and ➔ Greenhouse

p143l19.text: gas emissions from fuels. This also opened the way for the

p143l21.text: Gallon I   Measure of volume (dry or liquid measure) for which

p143l22.text: there   are   several   definitions.   The   US   liquid   gallon   customary   for

p143l23.text: measuring   liquids   in   the   USA   is   equivalent   to   around   3.785 litres.

p143l24.text: Gluten I   A tenacious elastic protein contained in cereal grains.

p143l25.text: It is used in the production of food products (particularly

p143l26.text: bakery goods) and special animal feeds. Gluten is of central

p143l27.text: importance   for   the   baking   properties   of   flour.

p143l28.text: GMP+ I   Guidelines for quality assurance of the production

p143l29.text: processes and environment, among other things, in the pro-

p143l30.text: duction of food and animal feed products.

p143l31.text: Grain year I   Period of twelve months for statistical purposes

p143l32.text: for collecting data (e.g., acreage, crop yields) for each type

p143l33.text: of grain. It begins with the start of the harvesting season. In

p143l34.text: Europe, the grain year for wheat runs from 1 July to 30 June.

p143l35.text: Greenhouse gases I   Besides methane, nitrous oxide and

p143l36.text: fluorocarbons,   ➔ Carbon   dioxide   is   the   main   anthropogenous

p143l37.text: greenhouse gas. The increasing concentration of greenhouse

p143l38.text: gases in the atmosphere is responsible for global warming.

p143l39.text: HACCP (Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point) I   A sys-

p143l40.text: tematic preventive approach in worldwide use for analysing

p143l41.text: hazards and monitoring critical control points in the ­production

p143l42.text: of food and animal feed to ensure health safety.

p143l43.text: IFS (International Food Standard) certification I   Certification

p143l44.text: and auditing of systems for guaranteeing the safety and

p143l45.text: quality   of   food   in   the   production   process.   The   certification   is

p143l47.text: Inside information in accordance with Article 17 of MAR I

p143l48.text: T   he “Market Abuse Regulation” (MAR) prescribed by the EU

p143l49.text: aims to prevent insider dealing and market manipulation.

p143l50.text: Article 17 makes it an obligation to publish market-relevant

p143l51.text: information so that other market participants are not dis­

p143l52.text: advantaged in relation to company insiders. Listed companies

p143l53.text: such as CropEnergies AG need to publish this information on

p143l54.text: an ad hoc basis, i.e., as soon as possible.

p143l56.text: I   Brand name for the ➔ DDGS   produced   by

p143l57.text: CropEnergies. It is marketed as high-grade protein animal feed.

p143l59.text: I   Brand name for the ➔ CDS   produced   by

p143l60.text: CropEnergies   in   Wanze.   It   is   a   liquid   animal   feed   with   a   high

p143l62.text: Rectification I   A step in the ethanol production process in

p143l63.text: which the ➔ Alcohol   is   purified   and   residues   are   removed.

p143l64.text: Renewable Energy Directive I   Directive 2009/28/EC of the

p143l65.text: European Parliament and Council of 23 April 2009 for ­promoting

p143l66.text: the use of energy from renewable sources. Among other things,

p143l67.text: this sets a mandatory target quota for ➔ Renewable   energies

p143l68.text: of 10% of the total fuel consumption in the transportation

p143l69.text: sector by 2020. The directive also contains rules on the sus-

p143l70.text: tainable production of ➔ Biofuels.   Economic   operators   are

p143l71.text: required   to   establish   independent   verification   procedures

p143l72.text: (e.g.,   certification   systems)   to   prove   compliance   with   the

p143l73.text: legally stipulated requirements. The last amendment was

p143l74.text: made by means of the 2015/1513 directive (“iLUC Directive”)

p144l1.text: Scope I   Classification   of   the   greenhouse   gas   (GHG)   emissions

p144l2.text: arising during production. Direct (scope 1) GHG emissions

p144l3.text: come from sources which are the property of or managed by

p144l4.text: the reporting company (e.g., own power stations). ­Indirect

p144l5.text: (scope 2)   GHG   emissions   result   from   the   generation   of   electric

p144l6.text: or thermal energy which the reporting company has ­purchased

p144l7.text: from third parties for its own use.

p144l8.text: Severance payment cap I   The upper limit on the amount of

p144l9.text: compensation that a member of the executive board receives

p144l10.text: if his contract is prematurely terminated.

p144l11.text: Stillage I   Residues of non-fermentable substances produced

p144l12.text: during distillation. Its content of protein, nitrogen compounds,

p144l13.text: fat and other substances make grain stillage a valuable ­animal

p144l15.text: Sustainability certification I   Serves to monitor and audit the

p144l16.text: entire cultivation, supply and production chain for ➔ Biofuels   to

p144l17.text: ensure compliance with the EU requirements of the ➔ Biofuel

p144l18.text: Sustainability   Regulation   through   independent   certification   sys-

p144l19.text: tems and bodies recognised and overseen by the EU ­Commission

p144l20.text: or national supervisory authorities (e.g., the Federal Institute

p144l21.text: for   Agriculture   and   Food   [BLE]   in   Germany).   This   certification

p144l22.text: also covers power generation from liquid biomass.

p144l23.text: Sustainability criteria I   Criteria that ➔ Biofuels   used   for

p144l24.text: the purposes of meeting the targets of the ➔ Renewable

p144l25.text: Energy Directive and ➔ Biofuels   benefiting   from   national

p144l26.text: support programmes are required to satisfy as proof of their

p144l27.text: ecological sustainability. Examples are a minimum reduction

p144l28.text: of ➔ Greenhouse   gas   emissions   and   the   protection   of   areas

p144l29.text: of high biological diversity. Social sustainability criteria were

p144l30.text: also taken into account in the drafting of the ➔ Renewable

p144l32.text: Volume percent (volume concentration) I   Written   as   vol.-%

p144l33.text: or v/v. In the case of ➔ Ethanol,   designation   for   the   ➔ Alcohol

p144l34.text: content   of   a   fluid   based   on   the   volume   at   20°C.

p144l35.text: Weight percent I   Measure of the percentage of the mass

p144l36.text: of one component relative to the total mass of a mixture
